description:
I absolutely love this place! I live a few blocks away and come in here a for coffee and breakfast sandwiches (ham and cheese is my fav!). The decor is quirky but incredibly charming. The baristas are so sweet and always greet customers with a smile. I am so glad this place is in my neighborhood! 

The only thing to note is that it is cash only, but they have lots of signs warning you and an ATM to make it easy to make a purchase.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
This review is a long time coming. I live a block away and even in coffee desperation I try not to come here because it is THE WORST. Here's some of the top issues 

* The coffee tastes burnt and always gross. 
*They don't take credit cards, the ATM in the corner never works and wastes your time with stupid signs written on it "if it doesn't work, try it again". Are you kidding me? Take my credit card like every other establishment in 2018. At the very least, have an ATM machine that works. 
* the staff is always rude. Always. 
* I was the only person in there once and they made me move tables cause I was at a no laptop table. I'm not exaggerating... I was the only human inside. 

I ain't no snob, but I do expect more than this half assed and poorly executed shop with mean staff and nasty coffee.
author: Jeannine R.

description:
CASH ONLY!! 

Stopped by for a coffee. Cute quirky interior, discourages use of laptop. Lots of boardgames and toys for lil kids. 

Americano was great.
author: RachEl L.

description: Local corner coffee house.  Family owned business which I love to support . They have pastry and breakfast sandwiches along with salads and also vegetarian sandwiches as well.  Place is filled with people who live in the neighborhood or tourist stopping by the cable car museum.
author: Stephanie C.

description: It's great that they provide WiFi and plenty of outlet. However, it's a "cash-only" store! And the coffee wasn't that good to be honest...If you don't mind and just need a place to work, it's not a bad choice.
author: Mike H.

description: This is one of the best-looking coffee places I have been in. The coffee is good and the staff is really friendly. It is also very cozy and friendly for computer users. But if you don't want to use a computer you can socialize, with playing board games or do some other things that they offer.
author: Špela Š.

description: I love coming here and getting my morning coffee fix. The staff are very friendly and they already know my by name! :) love this neighborhood gem.
author: Ly L.

description:
Wow. This place is such a find! Came in hungry with my husband and two small children, and was so impressed with the friendly service, delicious food, and fun kid-friendly atmosphere! This spot obviously caters to the "big kid" in all of us, as it's stocked with board games, vintage toys, and fun decor, but the staff welcomed my small active kids and encouraged them to play with the awesome toy trains. This was probably one of the most relaxing meals out we had with our kids during our trip. 

We will definitely visit again!
author: Lauren T.

description:
Step back in time and enjoy a forgotten era of American history influenced by the age of World War II. Complete with hanging comic books of Amazing superheroes, the music of the Andrew Sisters, Tommy Dorsey, and an antique cafe full of books and other nostalgic memorabilia. It's a true step back to an era where America stood tall, proud and united. A historical vintage television sits im front of a movie screen with a hand taped sign that reads "Creature Feature Tuesday" while the San Francisco trolly cars bustle past and rounding the corner just off the cafe entrance. 

The menu caters to all diets. Granola and yogut, egg covered english muffins, drinks, and handsome meals a plenty to offer any patron. 

The aromas pour out the open glass doors towards the Cable Car Museum. Such an amazing little treasure. Easy to miss. So make a point to put the Gallery Cafe on your breakfast /lunch/ brunch must visit list when you visit San Francisco.
author: Marc B.

description:
In A Nutshell:

-Stopped by Gallery Cafe during a segway tour of the city.
-This is a corner shop that is filled w/ nostalgic items like old games, b&w T.V., etc...
-Just grabbed some cold drinks since it was San Francisco's 10th ever hottest day (100+ degrees).

Overall, nothing too fancy to report about this place, it's an average spot.
author: Romeo K.

description:
Everything under $10! This cafe is sooo cool! It has a friendly, quirky vibe and playful decor. The breakfast bagel and sandwich we tried were very good! We would definitely come here again.

P.S. The cable car museum (free) is right across from the cafe :)
author: Cyrina Y.

description: Great neighborhood spot with a mix of tourists (cable car museum is across the street) and locals. Playful clutter with board games, books, and movie nights. The hot chocolate is a win, the coffee is okay, and the bagel options are delicious.
author: Jay K.

description: I was considering a three star just because my husband ordered an iced coffee and got a hot one lol .. but he said the coffee was still good. I asked for an iced tea and was offered green or black, my green tea was perfect! I don't like sweet things and there was minimal (if any) sugar added, with options to add if I wanted. The atmosphere was great, very low key and relaxed with a fun barrister on the counter. If back in the area I would return. But would confirm my order just in case ;-)
author: Sarna B.

description:
If you are looking for an interesting coffee shop this is it! I wouldn't come here daily, or maybe I would...? But I definitely felt amused and enjoyed the hour and a half I spent here one afternoon while on a trip to SF. This is unusual to the max! Crazy decor, funny little notes, and no laptop signs on certain tables. Board games for days, unique music, and they have bad yelp reviews hanging in the bathroom! 

Don't become a review on the wall of shame y'all! Come enjoy a nice mocha made w Ghirardelli chocolate, play some board games and chat with friends!

Important: they don't take cards!! Clean bathroom . Oh and across the street is the free admission cable car museum definitely check that out as well!
author: Faisal A.

description:
Pricey + Rude people working there . Those Asian ladies are a nightmare to deal with , you gotta go there and ask them for something to know what I am talking about .

Ill give you 2 stars just for the creative decoration.
author: Martin M.

description:
Don't be fooled by the "cool atmosphere", this place doesn't deserve your business. Why?

- Extremely rude service consistently
- Doesn't accept credit cards, cash only
- Way overpriced

Today, I had another terrible interaction with one of their rude baristas. Not coming back.
author: Levent S.

description:
Great coffee from a staff who is personal and friendly. They remember exactly how I like my cappuccino even though I don't get in very often.

What a refreshingly local difference from corporate coffeehouses!

Great bagels and top quality espresso.
author: jack l.

description:
First of all, do not come here underdressed. There is a dapper gentleman named Robert (a regular) that is always dressed "to the nines." Once you see his plethora of stunning outfits, you will be forced to question your own wardrobe, and quite possibly your life. 

Second of all, it's okay to come here underdressed. There is a long-haired fellow that works here that wears "Lion King" and "Superman" t-shirts, and he's not a child. 

Third of all, if you do not have a stellar singing voice, do not come here. There is a cook that has an amazing singing voice and will often belt out tunes (singing along with the music in the cafe) that will make you feel musically and vocally challenged. You'll quite possibly wonder if you truly have any talent at all.

Fourth of all, if you are absolutely atrocious at singing, it's okay to come here. The aforementioned long-haired fellow has a singing voice that's worse than you've ever heard. Far worse than even your own. Guaranteed. It may actually be the worst humanity has ever heard, but it does not stop him from utilizing it. I believe he does this to clear the place out when he wants to go home and play video games.

Fifth of all, there is what appears to be a nice young woman behind the counter, but do not be fooled. She is a savage, ruthless gambler and will take you for every last penny you have. Be warned.

All in all, a great place, although they only accept American Express Black Cards and Bitcoin.
author: Kurt A.

description: Don't be fooled by Levent S. Or the guy who recently left a one star review. I can attest the baristas are super nice, very polite and have a great sense of humor! I can see how an old man with a stick up his butt could confuse their humor for rudeness but I frequent this cafe and often come to play chess and have a bite to eat or a latte so I'm usually in there for an hour or two at a time and I have never seen a rude interaction between baristas and customers. I hope to see levant's review on the wall 'O shame soon  keep up the good work y'all!
author: John S.

description: Wow what a fun quirky place great food and drinks ... Checkout the wall o shame in the bathroom
author: Tom I.

description: My go-to coffee shop for studying. Close but just far enough away from the busy streets of Chinatown. There are plenty of outlets alongside one wall, and they don't kick you out or make you repurchase food/drinks every couple of hours if you're using their wifi (though it would be nice if you did!). It can get noisy with the Cable Car museum right across the street, and with the steady flow of traffic from tourists coming in and out, but this place has solid food, coffee, and I'm a fan of their unique and cool decor. Cash only! ATM machine inside (for a fee).
author: Vickie Z.

description:
This place has a really cool vibe.  Lots if funky stuff along with small jokes...  

There are tables with poles in the center showing a card :   " No laptops - conversation table"

lots of books , games ( saw customer playing chess with barista) , and free New York Times to read ( with note asking you not to steal it)

But the most important part was coffee was great, food fresh and good, and pretty reasonable.

CASH only - which is common in Chinatown (which this is next to) but ATM right by registrr

And the inside decor was probably best I've seen!

Not generic- that's for sure.   Gallery Cafe is across the street from the Cable Car Museum, and it looks like someone who cares decorated it.  Yeah, obligatory trains, but also very cool photos of SFO.

Music, unusually enough is 'roots' Country.   

I would never mix all these ingredients- which is why I don't own the coolest / best coffee shop I've been in
author: Steve B.

description:
Food is delicious... a bit pricey for what you get but wonderful atmosphere and amazing customer service!
Lots of fun games for the kids and adults alike to play to pass the time. Also no cell phone and computer rules at the tables! Forcing people to actually interact with one another want to eat! Love it!!!
author: L G.

description: Wow! What an incredible place! I felt my inner child come to life as I was surronded by the vintage toys and games. The service was incredible and I had the most delightful cup of cappucino. I highly reccomend this local and unique experience.
author: Lizzie L.

description:
Hidden gem. 

My favorite spot in the city.  Great atmosphere, great food, great beer, great coffee, fun decor, friendly staff, and tons of board games.

The patrons here always seems super happy.  Its a great coffee shop that you feel like you can just "hang out" in.  Reminds me of that coffee shop in Friends, except with a lot of kitsch knick knacks all over the place.  You could call this place hipster, except I haven't really seen many hipsters here.  The Gallery attracts all types: Nob Hill yuppies/techies typing away on their laptops, old friends from Chinatown catching up in Cantonese while sipping a beer, parents who want to grab a coffee while their kids play Connect Four, tourists taking a break after checking out the Cable Car Museum across the street, couples on dates, and even a gang of motorcycle cops!  (There is great people watching outside as well, like the time I saw a tourist try to get a picture ON one of the SFPD motorbikes...)

They have a bookshelf that you can borrow books from.  I really appreciate this on days that I want to grab a coffee by myself and not get distracted by my phone, like I would at Starbucks or Peet's.  

If you're here with a friend, they have loads of board games including: Battle Ship, Connect Four, Stratego, Candy Land, and more!  They also have Rubik's Cubes and other puzzles for those flying solo.

Before getting distracted by games and books, take time to explore the place, there are fun knick knacks everywhere including an old movie projector, an electric train set, and much more. They also have movie nights, which I haven't attended yet, but want to check out.
author: Andrew H.

description: Had roast beef sandwich.  Great little cafe with a great vibe.  Nice staff and clean restroom.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Holy wow cutest and most creative lil cafe I've ever seen. Not to mention food and drinks are amazing! Recommend the joe sandwich !!
author: Chloé B.

description:
Yesterday I had the pleasure of stumbling into this gem. We had one day to explore SF and I'm so glad this place made it in the list. Dexter was amazing and made my boyfriend and I feel at home.  Nothing short of chatting with an old friend. 

Thank you so much for letting us step back in time!
author: Ashley D.

description:
This place is hilarious with it's attitude! loved the door o' shame, cubicle and silly talking tables. The latte wasn't anything special but i loved the grilled chicken sandwich on sourdough! 

In general fun atmosphere!
author: Kartik T.

description:
This place does not give a $hit about keeping up with the Joneses, and I respect them for that- expect the staff to be a bit gruff with you, the place a bit dingy (or loved, however you want to see), and the menu simple. No iced coffee, but they will pour some hot coffee over ice for you-

It's also cash only, but there's an ATM on site if you find yourself short of cash.

I imagine this is exactly the type of place where you could become a regular and that the owners would come to your wedding. If you're used to snazzy coffee shops and posh espresso drinks, then this isn't the joint for you.
author: Elliott W.

description:
Found this Great cafe while walking around on a Sunday.
With some good beers and a funky eclectic vibe. 
Plus board games available and friendly staff this was a great find
author: Chris L.

description:
Walked in on a whim with an almost finished $3 iced tea from Starbucks, ordered $9.50 veggie chili, told to take it to go since we had "outside food". I was floored. 

If we had stayed to eat, I would have purchased another tea. 

Rude & money lost for them? Not returning...
author: Katie E.

description: Excellent Coffee, Fast Service, Good Place To Work/Chill.  The kitchen makes good simple food from a short menu.  I live around the corner and drop by often.  Once a month they play an old movie at the end of the day.  Last night it was the original King Kong, on a movie projector!  I get the impression the owners are not doing this only for the money.. clearly there is an expression of creative energy and passion they have for their cafe.
author: M B.

description: Great little place for morning coffee and bagel.  Fresh squeezed oj was yummy, eclectic atmosphere made for a fun experience!
author: Laura K.

description: What an awesome experience we stumbled upon this place on our way to the wharf. We decided that we wanted to have a drink and popped in for someone the prices are amazing for the location. But the best part about it is a customer service and the people working there specifically Dexter. I highly recommend this place if you're in the neighborhood. And sw
author: Kerin S.

description: Love this place! Stumbled in it on our way to the cable car museum. Very fun relaxed vibe and yummy breakfast!
author: Deb S.

description:
My favorite community atmosphere in SF after a year of being here. Leaves behind the sterility of 3rd wave coffeehouses and embraces a personality local to the people who work there. 

Love that tuna melt
author: Zane J.

description: Sweet little spot with plenty to look at while sipping my tea. Right across from the Cable Car Museum. Great lunch spot too.
author: Anna H.

description: Great local food in an eclectic restaurant! Want wifi? You got it! Want to play board games. Travel no further. Got kids? Perfect spot. Kind owner who takes orders and serves his customer. Right here. Vegetarian? He's got it! He even has a vegan dish that is gluten-free. Need a book to read while eating here? He's got that too! Customers who are kind to you even if they don't speak your language? The atmosphere brings the best out of people here. Great restaurant, owner, atmosphere, and food! It was worth it for us to drop by here as a part of our trip to San Francisco! Before or afterwards, check out the Cable Car Museum right across the crosswalk.
author: Nathanial I.

description:
This is my favorite cafe in the city! It's located right across from the cable car museum, so you hear cable cars and wheels and bells outside - very San Francisco and very romantic (in my opinion).

The cafe itself is really quirky and creative. There are a lot of board games, old toys and odds and ends (like a projector, a typewriter), books, and lots of decorations and posters with funny quotes. They even posted up all the terrible yelp reviews written about them, which was pretty amusing.

The owners are father and son. Haven't met the father but the son is friendly. It's nice to go to a cafe and talk to the owners - makes it more like something you can only find in the neighborhood!

Have yet to actually try their food. Chai latte wasn't bad - pretty typical. The overall vibe of the place, though, makes it totally awesome for just sitting and chilling in the city.
author: Julianna K.

description: Cash only. Well known to locals. Encouraging their guest to talk to each other while dining. Lots of table games to play and books to read.  No sport games allowed  on their tv.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Quaint little eclectic old-school SF experience. Typical menu of espresso drinks, breakfast/lunch, and dinner items. Didn't have it, but the Mac & Cheese looks amazing! 

I went at a very busy time and my order got lost in the shuffle, which wasn't a big deal. The staff and owner felt so bad, they offered to refund my money, which I didn't accept, so they upgraded my order for free and comp'd my 2nd coffee and a pastry! Truly above and beyond my expectations!

There's some cute outdoor seating under the trees across from the Cable Car Museum, which is fun to watch the cars roll by from both directions! There's also boardgames and books for available, which great to keep the kids occupied.

I'm a fan!
author: Derwood A.

description: This is a very chill place. Been here a few times for their tuna melt sandwiches and it has never failed to amaze me. I have yet to come here for study purposes, however I feel like this Café  would make a terrific place for it. Seriously though, their tuna melt sandwiches and a cup of coffee during a sunny afternoon is PERFECT!
author: Johnny N.

description: Coffee is nothing special, but the place has a nice vibe, staff are cool, and is laptop friendly. There's power strips along the bench on the wall, and wifi speeds were 12d/3u one morning I was there, with a few others scattered throughout also on laptops. Beatles tunes were playing in the background, bonus. Decent spot for the neighborhood!
author: Linus W.

description:
Super laid back coffee shop located right across the cable car museum. 

I come here whenever I am in Chinatown to pick up a decent cup of coffee for an affordable price. 
I usually stick with a small coffee, I love how they have all different choices of milk for free and don't Nickel and dime you if you want some almond milk in your coffee. 

The setup of this shop is a bit weird, it is located on different levels And the cashier is like 1-2 ft lower than you.  They have a lot of books and board games here as well ! 

Come here if you're looking to grab a quick cup of joe to go or want to chill before exploring the rest of sf.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Came here for breakfast on a sunny Saturday morning. Great choice of food - chose the egg and cheese on a muffin and we had a great cappuccino and the biggest cup of tea. Helpful staff and cool interior with film posters and an old film showing on the TV. A few tables outside too. Will definitely visit again.
author: Elaine S.

description: Hands-down this is our new favorite café in San Francisco. We came across it during a Sunday walk in Nob Hill. In fact a neighborhood resident on nearby Clay Street suggested we head there when we asked about local spots for casual, healthy food. The BLTA on focaccia and a salad with fresh chicken and a latte -- all for under $20!!! -- lovingly freshly made. Yummers!  Love the signs that indicate where you can sit with your laptop and those tables reserved for chatting. Lively without being loud when we were there, friendly and unhurried service, outdoor seats if we had wanted.  Simple, like home, if you cook healthy. Not precious.
author: Joan O.

description:
Advertises fresh coffee but my Americano was worst than Starbucks! Never going back.

The place was nice, and they had tons of games. It seemed cool, but no no to the coffee quality.
author: Liana H.

description:
Love this accidental find. Fun and friendly staff. Great kitsch, cold beverages, plenty of power outlets and a real neighborhood feel. We only had tap beers and cold beverages during our hour stay. 

We didn't have anything to eat as they were out of a few things. Could have been more sanitized but one staff member was constantly washing his hands which brought me joy! 

The interior had so many fun things to relax about, old movies, fun games, amusing seating, friendly banter. I will try to come back to this off beat place across from the Cable Car Museum.
author: Chris M.

description:
Wait Time: 5-10 Minutes for Food. 

Unique Factor: 3/5 - Gallery Cafe feels like a time capsule when you walk in. The interior decor is strategically cluttered. Some of their menu items are somewhat random, feels as if the kitchen staff decided they wanted to try a recipe, so they added it to the menu for the day. In a way, that is what makes the cafe feel like home. You can get a panini and a chocolate bomb all at the same place. 

Service: Friendly Staff, with a lot of local customers. Cash Only.
author: Vivian Y.

description:
I really really want to love this place, but there are such glaring problems that it's hard to. I live about 30 seconds from this spot, so I've been in a few times over the past few years. I visited again today because I needed to do some work on my laptop, and didn't feel like staring at the usual scenery. 

The Good: 
* The decorations and atmosphere are super cool. There is a large area for books and magazines, creative wall accessories, board games, and I'm pretty sure they screen classic movies on some nights in this little area with couches and movie theater seats.
* They recently added a "cubicle simulation" corner that is slightly separated from the main seating. It's only enough room for 1 person, but it's a cute sectioned off area for someone looking to use their laptop with more privacy. 
* They have a decent amount of outlets and extensions cords for plugging in devices.

The Bad:
* The food. The food is incredibly pricey for a café. Yes, even in San Francisco. The breakfast sandwiches are small, and VERY bland. I don't think they use salt or pepper at all. To make the most out of your money, I suggest getting a bagel with cream cheese, as it seems to be the only affordable option in terms of quality and quantity. But get there early, because they only allot a certain amount of bagels per day, and they run out of options quickly.
* The coffee (depending on who is making it). It's just...not good. I've had drip coffee from here a few times and it's usually very weak. I was surprised when I had an amazing latte from here this morning. The ratio of milk to espresso was perfect, and there was an adequate amount of foam. I decided to get another because the first was so good, but the woman made it this time, and it was really bad. Tasted burnt, and there was no foam at all. Not even a hint. I couldn't finish it. She was pushing out coffee drinks so fast that I doubt anyone had any quality to their coffee order.
* The "Cash-Only" policy. If things weren't so expensive, I could get over this. Can't you install a square reader? Apple pay? It seems that this might be a nod to their attempts at making this spot more nostalgic of older times when stores only accepted cash, but I think they'd get more service and even be able to up-charge more if they offered other ways to pay.
* Finally, the service. I've had good experiences with the guys here, I'll give them that. They're polite and friendly- what you'd expect from any basic customer service interaction. But when it comes to the ladies who work here, that's another story. I'm not sure what her name is, but there's an older asian woman who dresses with lots of cleavage (totally fine, just not sure how else to describe her). Anyway, she's INCREDIBLY loud. She screams everyones order, it's really alarming. I've also found that she is only nice to the male customers. I've witnessed this more than once while there. She gives the female customers a ton of attitude for no reason, and then openly flirts with the men. I even overheard her today joking with a random guy about how he should have said "thank you ~princess~" instead of just thank you. Super weird. She also openly yelled at this younger girl working the register, in front of all of the customers. Just really unprofessional and off-putting.

It seems that they do try to present this "hard-ass", "dgaf" attitude on purpose, like it's part of their schtick, but the atmosphere of the place seems oddly contradictory to that kind of demeanor. If this were a café connected to Zietgiest, I'd get it. But it's not. It seems like they really need to re-think their staff, as well as their menu. Focusing on at least putting out good coffee would really be a step-up.

P.S. they print out negative Yelp reviews and tape them to the back of the bathroom door for you to read while using the facilities. So, I'm sure this will be on there at some point. Hi everyone!
author: Ally H.

description:
A whimsical little cafe located right across the Cable Car Museum.

As soon as you walk in, you're greeted with friendly faces, and it's occupied by the local regulars. It's easy to spot the owner's love for comics and monsters with a rendering of Godzilla in downtown NY on the roof of the entrance. There's a book shelf filled with classics donated by the owner, and you can even do a book swap if you're feeling nostalgic.

What really did it for me was that this was something unique that you could probably only find in SF. The chicken noodle soup was home-made and outstandingly soulful. Loved every sip of it. If I had space in my belly, I would have ordered a few more helpings. Actually, thinking about it right now, I'm missing it already. 

The service was super friendly and immediately made us feel like we were at home. Definitely will be back... especially for that chicken noodle soup.
author: Natalie W.

description: This place had amazing food and great decor. The walls would be covered in funny signs and pictures. If you looked up you could see fighter planes shooting off rockets with cotton smoke. Besides the decorations the food was great. I had the egg and cheese sandwich on a English muffin. The egg was cooked to perfection and it tasted just right. Overall the Gallery Cafe was a great place to eat.
author: Eli B.

description:
Whereas I would describe most cafes in the city to feel modern and new, Gallery Cafe is one I would describe to feel vintage and cozy.

I used to come here on Saturday mornings with my dad when I was working part time for him on the weekends. It always felt comfortable to just sit within this cafe, sipping away at a cup of coffee. There would be other people chatting, reading, on their laptops, and some high school students helping each other out with what I presumed to be SAT prep. It's just like any other cafe, but with a nice vintage look. There's an old TV set in one corner, some record players lying around, a bookshelf of old books, some old artsy photographs of the city, some board games, etc. I just love the feel of this place as it makes me feel calm and as if in a different time. And before I get lost in all this atmosphere talk, the coffee is great too! :D
author: Joshua M.

description: Gallery Cafe is located right across from the Cable Car Museum. If you're around the neighborhood, good spot to grab quick breakfast sandwiches, croissants and bagels.
author: Christine C.

description: Probably the most nostalgic cafe for 90s kids. Cash only, mouse trap, toy train sets, and a plethora of mismatching chairs. Insanely charming spot, and the coffee and food is just fine. Cash only is still a bug for me, though.
author: Winston S.

description: Very cool, completely unique spot filled like a museum with eclectic games, records and posters. The owner is very friendly and food well done. If your looking for a completely unique place to visit in SF, wander in here.
author: Eric S.

description:
I live and work near by.
The new owner is very kind and friendly and has really made the cafe much more friendly.
I think know the food is way better and my Son really enjoys coming here.he loves there soups..
I have never been told I can't sit at any particular table with my laptop.They have even stayed open later so I can have a quick beer and a bit to eat when they have already started to turn off the oven.
I have had nothing but very nice service.
Thank you Gallery Cafe.
author: Connie B.

description:
Four stars only because my husband did not like his breakfast sandwich. The lady at the front counter was pretty bitchy but I didn't mind it. Even the yelp review they posted on the bathroom door said that service was bitchy! Lol 
The lattes were phenomenal and the rest of us (three other people) enjoyed our breakfast. We also liked that we were able to play games during our breakfast and hang out without touching our phones!
author: Melanie N.

description: Annoyed at their service. Hubby bought a $4 mocha. While he drank it, I fed the baby some bread (admittedly that we bought earlier in the day from another store). The manager came over and asked us to leave because the baby was eating "outside food". It's a baby - come on....
author: Wendy A.

description: My daughter and I were looking for a coffee and breakfast place while waiting for the Cable Car Museum to open. We found Gallery Cafe right across the street. The menu is simple yet complex. The food is excellent and the decor is eclectic. I appreciated all the power strips under the tables so we could charge our phones. The wall of yelp sham in the bathroom is a hoot! Great place!
author: Sandy B.

description: Rude, cold, uncaring and impersonal service from the lady who takes orders at the register.
author: Reena C.

description:
My new favorite café! Board games & boardgames! Hot chocolate is a must, the vibe is super chill & the workers are amazingly welcoming/friendly! 

I will frequent this cafe on a more consistent basis..
author: La Mont D.

description: It's my 1st time visiting San Francisco and found this gem after visiting the cable car museum.  Small town feel in the big city! Friendly staff,  good coffee, comfy chairs, and cold beer. What more could a person ask for?
author: Mary C.

description:
FOOD:
Artichoke quiche = yumm hella good  comes with a little salad too 

SERVICE
Order at counter they bring it out using sailor moon playing cards haha. Downside cash only. 


ATMOSPHERE 
kinda basic but spacious has couches tables outdoor sidewalk seating bar seating handful of boardgames to choose from would be great place to play boardgames gas wine and beer too and good food. If coming in daytime great place to catch a drink or bite and go to the cable car museum right next door!!!! So cool. Also can see and hear the cable cars strolling by on Mason & on Washington. And get to feel like one of the tourists on an adventure in Nob hill central
author: Angela L.

description: Just a typical non descript café in SF I'd say. Games to pass the time so I suppose they're ok with an extended stay and the usual offerings of a small local coffee joint. Located right across the street from the Cable Car Museum we stopped in for a recharge during our touristy day. I liked the little corner with the projector and the movie theater seats.
author: Desmond F.

description: Quite possibly the worst coffee in the city. Maybe their food is decent but I've never tried it. This spot is right down the street from my friend's apartment and I've grabbed coffee here a few times for convenience but it's never good, tastes like dirt and water, and I keep hoping it improves but it never does.
author: Stefany V.

description: We had the Americano and coffee, my son and I were on vacation and decided to stop here to eat. The food, service and atmosphere was nothing short of superb!
author: Chris M.

description: Just across the road from the Cable Car Museum we decided to get an iced tea then stayed for a sandwich. We had a BLT with avocado and a beef on sour dough. Both were very nice. There are plenty of places to sit and books to read. There is even a lounge. The pick of the spots for us was at the window where you can see the cable cars come down Washington or swing into Washington from Mason.
author: Sue L.

description:
Love spending my WFH days at Gallery Cafe... good coffee, food, atmosphere! I think the talking/computer tables organization is great for those looking to socialize, vs. study or work. 

Also, make sure to check out the hilarious Yelp reviews posted on the bathroom door.... the owner clearly has a great sense of humor. :)
author: Patty M.

description:
stopped in on a whim for lunch, wont be back.  


(+) 
pretty decent roast beef sandwich.

(-)
had boba tea drinks with us, the owner/mgr when serving our food says gruffly, "for future reference we don't allow outside food or drink". it's not exactly a competing product and we spent 20 bucks there regardless??

not cheap enough to be cash only, sorry.

surveillance camera staring me in the face literally 12 inches away from our table. OKAY.
author: Matt M.

description:
Four stars for location, three stars for memories, two stars for new customer service.  

The old owners served mediocrity, but everyone was treated equally.

I came in today to experience huge smile towards another patron before me.  When it was my turn to order, I was greeted with a stiff smile and explanation of my order to confirm whether I knew what I ordered.  

I confirmed my order with an awkward yes (Yes, I can read.  Yes, I know what I ordered.  Yes, I drink dark and strong coffee.).  

It's sad my old stomping ground has become such an unwelcome place.
author: Michelle S.

description: I like the vibe at Gallery Cafe much much more since the new ownership. It's no longer snoozeville. The old-timey & monster sci-fi flair is exploding all up in here. It's super cute. Staff is friendly. I wish the menu had more options and that they stayed opened later.
author: J C.

description:
Stopped in to purchase a Gatorade and use the restroom :)

Item reasonably priced, restroom clean and roomy - nothing to complain about here. I likes the local art on the walls - and the cappuccino made for the person in front of me looked fantastic!
author: Kenneth B.

description:
Pretty solid little cafe.  Over priced for the quantity/quality of the food, but it has lots of window seating, plus outdoor seating, and books to read/games to play while you're there.

Adorable place, good coffee, okay food.  I'd go back if in the area, but not going to rush back.

Cash only, too.
author: Jes G.

description: Had a lovely time here eating a breakfast bagel. The place is very adorable and comfy. Would like to play board games at the tables near an antique TV set if I am in the area again -- the day happened to be epic and sunny , very nice and fresh air coming in around us
author: H K.

description: Great atmosphere with lots of nic nacks. It's in a classic part of San Francisco's Nob Hill, right across the street from the cable car museum. I am glad there's still places like this in SF.
author: Mikee C.

description:
Nice quiet and cozy cafe to catch up with a friend or to spend an afternoon working. Would recommend. 

Highlights: 
- Drinks and food are decently priced
- Free wifi
- Quite a number of tables to work on
- Clean washroom
- Staff are friendly and helpful (keys to washroom or wifi password)
author: Bernard H.

description:
Awesome place - the tables in the windows are perfect if you can get them. Great board game selection though I haven't gotten a chance to play any of them yet.

Right across the street from the Cable Car Museum / operation center - you can actually see the big wheels inside pulling the cables from some of the tables here.
author: Ken R.

description: Great coffee and ambience, we didn't have any food but the coffee (latte and Capp) was on point. Loved the old tv playing and the board games. Great little spot to relax in.
author: Summer C.

description:
This place turned hands in April, and they've made a lot of improvements to give it a great cozy, neighborhood feel with a lot of vintage touches. 

New additions to the menu include soups of the day, sausage cannelloni, eggplant parmesan, and a meatloaf sandwich all at fair prices. I've been told drinks can be made iced too (not sure if this was the case previously).

It's a great place to unwind and grab a beer to relax and read the newspaper! I like what they've done with the space. Only wish is that it wasn't cash only.
author: Denise R.

description:
My friend lives next door to this place, and I've made the mistake of going here twice.

Our first visit, we got the breakfast sandwich and lattes. We asked for no cheese yet both came with it anyway and they wouldn't remake it. I worked in coffee in college, and their espresso and steaming techniques were subpar.

The first time I thought they were just having an off day and gave them a second chance. Again, the sandwiches came with cheese. I asked for one latte to be made with soy yet it was made with milk. I came back from next door to have it remade, and the barista had an attitude with me. She made it correctly the second time. 

If you want rude, impersonal service with terrible coffee and only passing through as a last resort... Keep passing and go somewhere else. 
This place is only open as a tourist trap to the cable car museum. If you want real coffee with great service, go anywhere else.
author: Mitchell R.

description:
I almost never post reviews but after stumbling on this cafe on a day trip to Nob Hill, I can't help it!  

I showed up with my husband and two young kids (4&6) before going to the cable car museum. The owner was super welcoming, and several customers happily guided my kids through the multitude of treasures and entertainment spread all through the cafe (trains, mini movie projector, old timey phones, etc.). It just had a warm welcoming vibe, completely not touristy, very much a neighborhood feel. And the music was eclectic but fun and conversation-worthy!

The food was simple but good and well priced. When my daughter rejected the Mac n cheese (because of some cayenne), of course this place had the perfect substitute (edible by child plus not very expensive)-- a bowl of fresh oatmeal wii dried fruit!  Very happy with this find. We'll definitely be back.
author: Erica L.

description: The service / team is always super nice, the place is full of humor and antiquities and the Wifi works well. Add some great sandwiches to the mix and some board games and you have a kickass place to go to.
author: Fabien-Pierre N.

description: Nice cafe, good coffee, cool staff.  The music selection will make you want to blow your brains out.  I didn't know it there were that many songs by female vocalists accompanied by wishy washy folk rockers.  3 hours of continuous ear worming, weepy drivel.  My advice, is bring head-phones.
author: Bob F.

description:
Very cool location, new owners, hugely improved the place. I ordered a breakfast sandwich, and woofed it down. 

Staff is very friendly. Lots of tables and and great wifi.

Keep up the good work!
author: Taylor H.

description: Loved this place! Stopped in for a coffee break while legging it around San Fran. Lucked out huge! Friendly service. Great coffee. Coolest decor ever. And cool tunes playing all the while.
author: Jim D.

description: Nice place to go for Saturday morning coffee. Plenty of space to sit. Very comfy seats. Just in front of the building is cable car museum. Nice and friendly staff.
author: Veronika J.

description:
Located across the Cable Car museum, this cafe gets a lot of foot traffic from tourists. Casually decorated, I like the spaciousness of the cafe with the big windows facing Mason st. Makes for great time looking out the window while watching the excited tourists riding the cable cars  =)

Lunch time called for a healthy grilled chicken wrap on wheat ($7.35)  I had it to go and ate it while roaming around the neighborhood. Nice chunks of grilled chicken breast, lettuce, tomato and cucumber topped with caesar dressing. They went overboard on the dressing, so by the time I was done eating my wrap, my take out bag was also soaked and breaking apart :/

Their happy hour looks enticing since this area lacks watering holes. Maybe I'll come back for that!
author: Janice C.

description:
The owner/manager who took my order was rude to me and made me feel uncomfortable.  He was hesitant to serve me because the shop was closing in 40 minutes, which I thought was plenty of time. I was going to pay with a credit card, but the woman who takes payments pointed to the "no cash" sign and didn't even say anything.  So rude!  I had a roast beef sandwich and a tea, and while the food tasted pretty good, I don't feel like going back again.  They clearly don't want people to work on their laptops, given the "no laptop" signs 
everywhere.
author: Galina L.

description:
I live in North Beach and walk by this cafe daily. This neighborhood bosts so many amazing cafes and places to go! Gallery Cafe has all the looks of a cool spot which is why it is such a shame the owners/managers of the cafe make the cafe uncomfortable for its patrons - in my experience. In general they just seem like rude people. Their few servers have always been nice but not the Woman who takes orders at the register or the Man who works in kitchen and serves. Just this last month I have gone in 3 times.  Each time I was treated incredibly rude by the staff.  Today I ordered a tea and tried to pay with my credit card, the only way in which I could pay! Instead of understanding and being kind, they treated me like I was a criminal and I was aggressivley and rudely told to leave by a man from the kitchen who freaked me out a bit and caused a little scene as I tried to finish out a time sensative task I had started before leaving.  Gallery Cafe is the only 'Cash Only' Coffee Shop/Cafe I know of in North Beach and to make a customer feel bad because of their probable tax fraud is plain and simple - not right.  This place is always filled with tourists as the Trolley Museum is across the street. I honestly think the owners/managers of this cafe know they can get away with being rude,outdated and having bad service because of proximity and tourist demand. I wish the service matched the quirky cool decor of this corner cafe because I would like to hang here myself.  Alas - for me and for anyone visiting looking for authenticity, its just not worth it when theres 1 million other way better truly local spots within blocks.  #treatyourpatronswell #begoodtopeople

Here is a totally spot on list of the 10 best Coffee and Tea spots in Northbeach - via yelp 
bit.ly/2e09UAu

For the owners/managers
https://www.thrillist.com/eat/nation/cash-only-restaurants-the-case-against-cash-only-restaurants
author: Nathan M.

description: Yesterday I was there for lunch, I had a coffee, the which is from La Colombe and a scrumptious lox on a bagel served with cream cheese, cucumber, capers and tomatoes. I would have given four stars if the cashier were cheerful and less snotty. Sorry
author: Francesco R.

description:
A great spot to get some work done, to have a casual conversation, or to take a little break on your travels. Fairly quiet, rarely overcrowded, service from staff has always been friendly from my experience. It's not a hipster, gourmet coffee joint, and I love that it isn't.

Depending on my mood, I get a coffee or a beer. This is one of the few cafes in Nob Hill to serve beer. I also like the sandwiches here. I've never been disappointed with any of the food or drinks. They're not the sole reason you would come here, but they taste good enough and the price is comparable or cheaper to other cafes around San Francisco.
author: George L.

description:
Ordered my cup of coffee, walk over to the ATM, then noticed that it was out of service. The proprietor gave me the coffee for free. That's good service. The coffee tasted great. I'll be back here with some cash to spend some money.

The coffee is dark roast, so I got a large cup half coffee half water. It was great.
author: scott h.

description: Awesome Lox Bagel, and very nice people working there. I ate breakfast here every day during my last stay in SF.
author: Johannes B.

description:
Cute classic movie decor, friendly service, and tasty drinks. I had a cubano (espresso with brown sugar) and a hot cocoa. I liked that I could get the cubano decaf. The prices were very reasonable for the city.

It was good place to study. Nice to know where the talking tables are so you can steer clear if you want more quiet to focus.

A bit chilly on a winter day, but OK away from the door with a jacket. Maybe they could close the front door to keep the place warmer?

By the way, they have lots of board games! Plus it was fun to see the cable cars passing by.

Overall I really enjoyed my time here and hope to return next time I'm in the area.
author: Alisha K.

description: Quaint little cafe right across from the cable car museum. The decor inside is almost set about 60 years ago. There are games, and places to play cards. I typically do my laundry next door and order a latte during. Good coffee, good food, friendly service.
author: Thomas R.

description:
This is my new place! I love that it's not a small crowded coffee shop. Very big and lots of seating options. Every time I come in I actually try to sit in a different seat!(: cute little tables sit in the widow area, my favorite spot so far, pretty secluded. Usually the window seats are filled with people doing work on their computer, but lucky us they reserved one window table for coffee sippers only. 
Employees are very so awesomely friendly, always greeted with a smile. The young man (dex? Dax?) is very sweet, accommodating, very friendly and always up to something making this great coffee shop even better. 
They also have wifi, books and games on a shelf to look or play with while you enjoy your meal/coffee. 
Oh and they have beer! On tap for sure, not sure about bottles or wine. 
It is cash only but have an atm inside.
Comfy couch and outdoor seating, too!

so sad I'm only in a sublet for this month, I wish I had a gallery cafe on every corner of the block of which I live on!  Can't even think of a single bad thing to say about this place. 

Get coffee here! They also have (haha, sorry,not sorry! I can't stop raving about this place!) delicious cookies!!!
author: Molly M.

description: I love this place. Little spot across from the SF Cable Car Museum, quiet and enjoyable. Highly recommend
author: Michael O.

description:
Incredibly off-putting owner, who made not only patrons but also staff feel uncomfortable. Some staff members didn't know what "vegan" is - concerning for a food industry professional. Not that it really matters considering the total lack of nourishing vegan options. 

Watched the barista pour one espresso shot into a drink that I had ordered and paid for with 2 shots. 

Overall, weird and exclusive attitude from the establishment, and certainly don't come if you or any of your friends are vegan. I'm going to finish my dry "veggie" sandwich and look forward to eating a real meal elsewhere.
author: Ryan A.

description: I love to stay in the cafe. Always nice environment and relax! They have the separate room table for love buds and alone time. There is a laundry place next to it so I love to stay here when I am waiting for my clothes. XP they have a lot of arts and books that feel free to take look!
author: Yuzhen S.

description: This is one of our favorite breakfast places where my husband and I can relax in the morning.  Every staff at the coffee shop is very friendly and welcoming. We love the ambiance and get to enjoy the free books !
author: grace k.

description: Great customer service with a comfortable and inviting environment. English tea and americano was just right.
author: Michele G.

description: Laid back cafe, fun view of SF tourists as it is located next to a trolley route. Staff is super friendly.
author: Maria A.

description:
This is place is great but not perfect. The last time I was here, I found the customer service a bit slow at times especially at lunchtime. I like how they have a wide variety of board games though to kill time while waiting for the order as well as to have a little fun with friends.

Would come back though since this place is near where I work at.
author: Terrence C.

description: I often come here to work in the daytime as I find the space unique and creative. I love it's real neighborhood feel and friendly staff are very kind. The teas are cheap compared to the hipster/tech cafes that charge an arm and a leg for a simple green tea... Plus, all those cafes look the same.... !
author: Stanley B.

description: I come here often for breakfast. Typically the staff is great and the food is good. Today I called to check what time they close, I was told 6. Their hours recently changed so I wanted to make sure. I got there at 5:50 and was told they were closed. Ummm it's 5:50 you told me you close at 6! I was told by the man working they do close at 6 but the kitchen closes at 5:45. Why would you not tell me this on the phone when I called? I would have gotten there 5 minutes earlier. I really enjoy the atmosphere and coming to this little local spot, they just lost a customer.
author: Brittany C.

description:
This is my go to study cafe. It has everything I could possibly want in a study cafe: seats, table, wi-fi, outlets, bathroom, real food, good cup of tea and great service. If you're like me and you need background noise to study, this is the perfect place to study! 

There is cute little space that seems like it's own little private study space. Good for two people, but it just feel very homey when you go alone. 

The tea selection isn't huge, but you don't need it, the coffee is great as well. The food here is pretty good for cafe! It can get noisy because of the Cable Car, but it's part of the San Francisco experience right? 

I would come here again and again, just to do a bit of light reading. Trust me, you will feel like you are just taking a lazy day at home. The decor is so inviting and warm and bright all at the same time. They even have a couch area.
author: Cynthia D.

description: Adorable corner cafe. Lots of vintage artifacts. Friendly service. Sidewalk tables. Right across from the Cable Car Museum.
author: Patrick S.

description: Great gem in the city for a cozy spot. Breakfast here is great especially if you love bagels and the coffee is good. There is also free WiFi here so it's a great place to study / do work.
author: Esty Z.

description: We had lunch here before visiting the Cable Car Museum.  The food and coffee were good but the best part was the fun decor.  It is creative and humorous.  Even in the bathroom!  Kudos for someone letting their creative juices have some fun.
author: Cheryl K.

description:
Wow! I didn't know a cook could blow me so well! I ordered the veggie sandwich. Because I am vegan, I asked whether there was dairy in the artichoke spread. He assured me there wasn't, so I ate it. Later, I thanked him and asked him what is in the dip. He said "cream cheese." Thank you, Gallery Cafe for the bout of diarrhea that is sure to follow. Here's a tip: if you are vegan and you read vegetarian, do not even ask any questions. Just do not eat the shiesse.

So, thank you, ignoramus cook, who doesn't know that there is dairy in cream cheese or doesn't know that dairy is what it is.
author: D M.

description:
Ya sorry but not good
The regulars seem to only come in for a drink
Smart as the food was, not good
My order was even wrong
The coffee was nothing special
The price was to much for what the place is,
Kind of, almost, run down
Not comfortable at all
It is right across the street from the cable car museum, 
Which is why we stopped by
Has got to be better places is the area
Try some and give us a review, for when we come back
to the city
author: John R.

description: Cash only. Coffee tastes burnt. And they run out of bagels before 10am like every day!
author: Emily B.

description: Delicious almond milk latte and Americano drinking and great people watching across the street at the cable car museum. This cafe has big tables with games to play and space to work. It's cozy and friendly and a lively spot to stop and rest.
author: Karen A.

description:
This is an OK cafe. The fact that it's a big space is a great advantage, but the service is always kind of bitchy, the ATM rarely works, and everything is about $1.00 or $2 more than what it is down on/around Union Square. 

Sucky for locals but great business for tourists.
author: Cody R.

description: This coffee shop has a really cool vibe with antique posters and lots of toys/games for the kids and the young at heart.  It looks so inviting like a nice place to casually enjoy some coffee or hot cocoa and play some board games with your kids.  If you want more than that, however, this is not the place to go.  We were lured in by the atmosphere but the breakfast was barely edible and in fact my kids refused to eat any of it.  There went over $10 down the drain as the breakfasts here are overpriced (about $8 for the lox bagel sandwich and about $5 for an oatmeal).  The bagels were very generic and low quality according to my hubby.  I had the veggie sandwich wrapped in lettuce which was blah and the egg was a dried up little puck.  I ate it because I was hungry but did not enjoy it.  The latte was ok but not great.  Bottom line:  this is not a place I would recommend for actual food.
author: Lisa F.

description:
A spacious corner coffee shop across the street from the cable car museum. They have an assortment of breakfast sandwiches, bagels, oatmeal and cereal for breakfast. The coffee is piping hot, so beware.  A medium coffee (12 oz) before tax is $1.85. Coffee sizes are 8 oz, 12 oz, 16 oz and 20 oz. 

They also have 4 beers on tap, wine and a refrigerator full of sodas, juices and water if you're just looking for some hydration. 

Most of the employees are somewhat friendly, although there is one female employee who always greets me with a sharp "YES?", no matter how hard I try for a smile and a hello. 

Cash only. ATM available inside, fee is $2.50, best fee in the neighborhood!
author: Kaylie P.

description: I heard this place had new owners or a refurb or something to freshen it up. Not. There is crap in every nook and cranny, including an old toy train set on the bar. What???  . $7.50 for two coffee drinks coupled with two older Chinese men smoking outside (at the tables that have a big sign saying no smoking) makes this just another Chinatown dump. Sad because it could be a really cute place.  Oh, I forgot to mention the two overflowing trash canisters in the food prep area.
author: Holly H.

description: Great little spot to visit before or after the cable car museum. Good food, lots of board games available to keep little ones busy, etc.
author: Tom K.

description: This place is a great place to grab a latte and watch the cable cars! My husband, 6 year old and i walked down the hill from the fairmont hotel for a casual breakfast. Nice selection of pastries and assorted bagels plus great veggie egg sandwich! Prices were inexpensive. They are wi-fi friendly and also have chess and board games to play while eating - it's directly across from the cable car museum ( which I also recommend stopping in as its free )
author: Kim S.

description:
Best croissant sandwich I've had in a while. Also, best and cheapest breakfast we've had while visiting San Francisco. So good, we're back again before we leave. Forget the fancy Fairmont buffet!

Not 5 stars only because it's not very visually appealing inside.
author: Kristen M.

description: I went here 7/5/15 and got to watch the US kill it in the Women's World Cup.  I stopped in to visit the ladies' room before driving back to LA and wanted to have a beer instead of just using the facilities.  I'm glad I did -- the soccer game was highly entertaining and I had a great conversation with a guy sitting next to me.  I unfortunately was in a bit of rush and didn't get his number, but Mark and Dexter were kind enough to help me get in touch with him after the fact.  I'll be sure to stop in next time I'm in SF!
author: Teresa D.

description: My wife and I stopped in for a late afternoon snack on Sunday after a long day of traveling. We each had a delicious California salad. They had a nice selection of local beers, friendly service and a great atmosphere. Board games available was an added plus.
author: Joshua S.

description: Great place! Ambiance is perfect, with all the old stuff cluttering up the walls and nooks of the inside. And the corner location with the big windows and recessed seating... Perfect for reading a book. I take one star off for the annoying tourists that shuffle in from the cable car museum across the street. This is somewhat mitigated by the owner's designation of 'talking tables,' although that is rarely enforced.
author: Carter C.

description:
I'm new to San Francisco and decided to search for a cafe near my place that has nice ambiance, food, drinks, wi-fi, and isn't too expensive.  I found it at Gallery Cafe!
(This isn't to say other places would be similarly excellent though)

Upon walking in, I saw plenty of seating, and found a nice little table for two (though it's just me) in a banquet window.  There are actually two of these little alcoves, both with power-outlets for my laptop and good lighting.

I ordered the Grilled Chicken Panini which comes with tomatoes and caesar dressing, as well a side of mixed greens and balsamic vinegrette.  I also ordered a latte with a hint of syrup (they have a nice syrup collection) and everything came to less than $10.  The wi-fi is secured but they aren't shy about sharing the password.

There is an ATM available here and it's right on the corner of Mason & Washington.  Great Nob Hill/Chinatown location!
author: Jordan M.

description: I love Gallery Cafe. It is a quintessential San Franciscan owned by a third gen SF'er. I encourage everyone to come here. The people are nice and kind and the decor is so creative and unique. I can't get the feel at any other cafe in the city that I get in Gallery Cafe.
author: Dom R.

description:
For some reason Gallery Cafe doesn't show up on the Yelp search for nearby coffee and tea. It took a while to try it, but we finally stopped by on Christmas Eve.

Ordering was a pleasant experience. The folks behind the counter were nice and unpretentious. We ordered one espresso, an espresso macchiato, and a "Big Oat Bar". I enjoyed the presentation of the espresso drinks - it was simple (no latte art for the macchiato) but not in a bad way.

The macchiato itself was quite good; it didn't taste burnt or too bitter. The Big Oat Bar complemented the espresso...although I wouldn't get it by itself.

The cafe has many seating choices. There's a communal section made up of small tables lined up parallel to the counter. There are also many 2-seater tables along the large windows and in small nooks. A comfy-looking couch section is set up in one corner.

As other reviews have mentioned, the music is a little bit loud. If I came here to work I would probably bring earplugs. The acoustics make the cafe feel a bit empty, but it's easily overlooked. I enjoyed watching the cable car swing around the corner, and the big windows offer a lot of natural light and the promise of people-watching.
author: Alyssa W.

description: Great place. Friendly service and comfortable with a great selection of teas and beer on tap. Nice art, too!
author: Drew G.

description: AMAZING! For 2 years I walked past this gem without every going, major regrets. When I finally went to the Gallery Café I was so impressed, I made it a daily routine to get my coffee. I am really picky about my coffee; I think Starbucks has gone downhill with their white mochas. This place knows how to make REALLY GOOD iced white mochas! The food is pretty good too. It is right across from the cable car museum so naturally there are waves of tourists that come through, but where in SF are there NOT tourists? Every time I've gone in around 2:30-3pm it was pretty busy, but generally there are plenty of open tables. The only downside is that it's cash only.
author: Meghan N.

description: I was very upset with the situation i encountered at this cafe today. I used to really enjoy this neighborhood cafe and invited a group of friends to study together. It was freezing so we attempted to close the door near us which was causing a draft. The cafe manager/worker would not allow it. We then switched seats to a warmer location and he made us switch seats to a cooler, boxed in location because of these silly talking table signs. There were plenty of talking tables open. Being excessively strict/anal about rules for no good purpose is not respectful or considerate to customees.
author: Shaheen S.

description: I like the atmosphere and I tried to like the place. But people here including the lady at the cashier are just always rude. I would not recommend this place.
author: Mai S.

description: Not impressed with service. Caters more to tourists, and doesn't seem to care much about local/repeat customers.  But, it's a cute place with decent small menu.
author: Erin I.

description:
Blown service. For an extra $1, your Organic chai latte turns into an non-organic almond milk flop.
Auction off food by screaming across the counter. Make people pick up food from front of service counter line (no pickup spot), so it's super awkward having to dodge eager customers waiting to order. Place needs to sink and sprout something new. Food is decent at best.
author: Jordan S.

description:
Maybe I was just starving (had skipped dinner the night before and then breakfast that day), but the grilled eggplant panini was phenomenal. The sundried tomatoes and pesto sauce perfectly complemented the eggplant. 

The place was cute too. Only 4 stars though b/c the iced chai was super overpriced.

Oh! It's a cash-only place.
author: Rowena L.

description:
Cash only!!

The biggest thing I loved about the Gallery Cafe was the building.  I know if you live in SF or any older city this may not impress you but the building is seriously old and beautiful.  Yes, the paint is peeling and the place has a sort of 'worn' feel but it is located on a corner with lots of windows and light. 

The baked food items are okay.  They don't make them there or anything special so if you want to be blown away by that you probably won't.  They serve your average drip coffee and lattes but they are good.  Lots of people were working away on laptops so it seems good for that.  Lots of tourists thanks to the Cable Car museum so good for people watching.
author: Heather F.

description: Everything about this place is average. The food, drinks, and service is all fine, but what bothers me is the overall decor of the place. The Gallery Cafe looks like a rundown hostel, from the old, mismatched chairs, to the cheap floorboards. The place really needs some TLC. I usually only stop there if it's on the way and I'm desperate for caffeine.
author: Regina L.

description:
Cheap, fast, and delicious drip coffee. My boyfriend and I walked in here around 9am on a Friday morning and it wasn't very busy at all. Everything is cash only, and two coffees were around $5 or so.

I was happy to see that they were brewing La Colombe coffee, which is a favorite of mine. I'd definitely venture back here if I was looking for a quiet and relaxing reprieve and to take advantage of their free wifi for customers.
author: Megan K.

description: Love the bathroom door with all the "wall of shame Yelp reviews" can't make everybody happy. The dragon lady who rang up your order was hysterical, dare anyone to cross her. Her interactions are no nonsense but Definitely with a smile. One guy came back up to the counter. Complaining  that there were raisins in his girlfriends bagel. I dared her to pick out the raisins and toss them at him... she must have been Feeling nice because she just got him a different bagel. But she laughed st my date and gave it a serious nod.  Fabulous latte and great atmosphere
author: Redd G.

description:
My companion and I stopped in for a warm drink and a snack on our way to the Cable Car Museum across the street. It's an unpretentious little neighborhood place, with tables, a small lounge area, and wi-fi. The place has a "shabby chic" vibe, and the walls could stand to be repainted and the floor touched up. 

The menu sports the standard cafe fare: Sandwiches, pastries, cookies, tea, coffee, and muffins. I had a latte, which was warm. What else can you say about a latte? Anyway, it was a perfectly pleasant place to stop for a snack on a chilly San Francisco day.
author: Angela L.

description: Come here on business about every other month and was staying close to here. I ordered the grilled chicken panini. There is no crunch to the bread at all and it's actually cold. Very average. Cute nice place to get some work done but being from Arizona, surprisingly I find it to warm in the cafe. It's cooler outside. Just okay. Wouldn't come back unless I couldn't find anywhere else quiet and nice to work out of...
author: Lynsey T.

description: Stopped by here on a whim, and with a craving for an iced coffee. I ordered a iced soy latte. It was lacking so much flavor. I even added two spoons of brown sugar in hopes that it would add some sort of flavor in it, and it did not. I wouldn't get coffee here again, but it does seem like a nice, chill place to do homework.
author: Tiffany W.

description: I love this cafe .. friendly service .. good strong coffee.. ambience.. breakfast. . Sandwiches. .sweet. beer n wine .. a lot of choices. And most important is Free wifi and a lot of space. Just place you can hang out .. work and meeting people also watching cable running in front of cafe
author: js w.

description: The breakfast sandwich is served cold, with rubbery eggs. The coffee is decent, but the place gets crowded with tourists coming in and out from the cable-car museum across the street. Definitely not a good place to sit for a while to get work done. But decent if you need to grab a quick coffee.
author: Claire S.

description: The Gorgonzola Salad was awesome! Warm walnut and a pretty mix of cheese and green leave with a wonderful splash of balsamic dressing.
author: Rob J.

description:
I am often here as it's just a block away. Great place to do some work. Rarely crowded. Full of locals.. I general like it - decent espresso and pastries but

1) a super unreliable and unstable Internet
2) cash only
3) now a terrible live music on Sunday
author: Irina K.

description: Great food and coffee at a great price. Sourdough bread was great for the chicken sandwich. Coffee and atmosphere were perfect for idling.
author: Michael C.

description:
Pretty standard. It's great for a quick pop-in as service is pretty fast and friendly. Standard prices for standard coffee, maybe a little more on the high-end.

Was very disappointed with the oatmeal, because it was pretty much a $5 bowl of milk. Sure, there were oats in it, but I like my oatmeal a little on the (really-)dry side and this wasn't even remotely dry. In the end after finishing all the oats, there was at least an inch of plain milk at the bottom of the bowl. Ew. My boyfriend did like his breakfast sandwich though, so maybe that would have been a better choice.
author: Katie V.

description: Cash only... other than that: Great seating, decent outlet access, Wifi - and great coffee. PERFECT for a rainy day! Some tables are surrounded by little glass nooks - making it a perfect spot to study without headphones... for once ;P
author: Matt C.

description:
I love their lattes. At times there's a serious language barrier, and everything is rather expensive, but other than that I love going here.

The cafe is small, intimate and relaxing. Also, they serve beer(?!)
author: Tyler H.

description: This is the best cafe in nob hill. The food is great, staff is friendly, and the owner is almost always on-site to oversee the entire experience. Definitely try the breakfast sandwiches; they're tasty!
author: Brady G.

description:
A solid 3 stars from me. 
Hit or miss on the service and food. 
Good soy lattes, reasonable drink prices. 
Bagels, cereal, a few pastries, quiches, sandwiches and salads as well. Their bagels are purchased elsewhere and they run out sometimes. 

The people watching is great - it's right across the street from the Cable Car museum. 

Free WiFi password with a purchase and outlets (very important!) making this a great 'work from home' spot.

Cash only.
author: Sara P.

description: Good if you want to freeze, they insist on keeping the Windows open and when I asked if there was anyway of closing it, they just put their hand up and walked away.
author: Mark M.

description: The Gallery Cafe is a great place to start your morning with a strong cup of coffee, or flavorful tea.  The breakfast sandwiches are delicious, I particularly like bacon, egg, and cheese on an everything bagel.  The location has free Wi-Fi and is a great place to watch all of the tourists riding the cable cars.  If you need to escape the everyday mediocrity of Starbucks, or Pete's, give this place a try.
author: Adrian H.

description: This was my first time visiting "The Gallery Cafe." I ordered the Gravlax Bagel with cream cheese and a small latte.  The bagel was very tasty and the latte hit the spot.  Peter, and the rest of the servers were very friendly, I will be back to try the Grilled Panini.
author: Marry A.

description:
This place is literally just a block away from me so I end up here quite often. It's a great place for a to go coffee, working/studying or just chillin' a few minutes while watching the happy tourists swing by in the Cable Car. Free WiFi. The outdoor seating in the sun is nice!
It's a bit pricey but the chill lounge music and hipster art inside makes up for it.
author: Niklas A.

description: This cafe is literally a block away from my apartment, making it the most convenient spot to grab coffee/a bit to eat when I don't feel like venturing very far.  The grilled cheese with tomato is my favorite sandwich there, and the lattes are pretty good.  There's some seating outside, and there are cool tables alongside the windows.  Good local spot.
author: Mel G.

description: I've only had their almond milk latte here. The ladies behind the counter were nice. I came in when it wasn't busy so I got my order pretty fast. Having to pick up your order back at the counter you ordered from was a little weird. Usually cafes have you pick up from another counter. The latte itself was well-balanced (not too milky, not too strong on the coffee and has a solid foam on top). Serving size was a bit small than average, but if you're in the area and need coffee, this is a good place. Cash only.
author: HM N.

description: Just ok food and ok atmosphere. 3 stars at best. Place doesn't look very good either.
author: Armin A.

description:
I ran in needing to use the restroom...Got myself a drink so I would be a paying customer. After I paid, I was told the restroom was out of order. Sigh. 

The cups are a bit on the smaller size. However, the chai tea is pretty good. The woman who runs the place seems very sweet.
author: Margaret R.

description:
Overpriced. The lady cook dropped a bagel bottom on the floor and still served it to customers without telling them. Major health code violation, who knows what else everyone drops and still serves. Stay away!!!

Down the block is a nice store called cable car corner. Family run store, never dropped anything. He had to raise his prices to compete with gallery. Please support them instead. 

Bad gallery cafe. Stingy and overpriced. 
Good Cable Car Corner!!!!
author: Valerie F.

description:
I really like coming here to get some work done. Prices and food are reasonable. 

I ordered a small drip coffee today and the guy literally gave me 3 fingers of coffee in a smaller than usual paper cup. (The cup was only filled 2/3 to boot.) I said something like, "wow, that's a small coffee." And he just said "yep." And walked away. 

So...get a medium?
author: Colin M.

description:
Yeah, MEH. 

The sandwiches aren't bad, the pastries are eh, and drinks taste like they should..nothing special. But for their size, it really isn't worth it. I do like coming here to get some work done. I come here probably 2-3 times a week and always order a drink with my sandwich. So I would consider myself as a regular. However, I think I am done being a supporter of this place. After an incident, I don't think I will be coming back.

I was tutoring a student here because the local library was not open at that hour. I haven't had a chance to order a drink yet because I was in the middle of tutoring session. While I was working with a student, one of the owners came up to me and rudely interrupts our conversation to ask if I wanted to order something to drink. I told him " I will in a little bit" and turned back to my student. I thought he would just go after that, but he continues to talk saying how I can't sit here for this long and not order anything. I looked around and I noticed this place was half empty. I have NO idea why he felt the need to tell their regular customer to order something, especially when the place was not even packed. I told him again "I will in a few minutes" and he still found the need to say that I have to order something if I wanted to sit here. After that I just said ok. I thought it was VERY rude and unnecessary for him to do that. Sure, I sat there for 30 minutes not ordering anything, but I did give him the confirmation that I was going to order something in a few minutes. That and I am a freaken regular, what the hell! 

Honestly, even if I hadn't ordered anything, I was still helping the business by attracting others to come inside. Hell no I am not giving this place any more business. RUDE owners. They do not know how to appreciate their customers.
author: Annie T.

description:
The Gallery Cafe has me hopeful about my new neighborhood. Stopped in while on a break from unpacking this week and ordered a lemonade to match with the sun. It was perfect. I am looking forward to sampling more from their menu.

Love the space. Dig the boy workin' the counter (his eyeliner added extra flair).

Will definitely be back.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Note to self: Never hike up Mason St. from Market.

This place served your everyday sandwiches. A little expensive and cash only. Not really a place I would go often. But you know who would?

Hipsters.

Super chill music, crazy art on the wall, quiche, coffee and expensive sandwiches.

It might not be my cup of tea, but if you wear thick framed glasses and tight pants; shop at Goodwill or Salvation Army; and ride a fixed gear bike, this place is for you.
author: Dorian T.

description: Pleasant stop for a coffee or tea. I liked the apricot bar.
author: Mark C.

description:
A little over-priced but really good... I used to frequent the Gallery Cafe when I lived right around the corner. It's also right next to a good laundromat so it's a great place to hang out while your clothes are sudsing. 

I highly recommend their iced coffee and cappuccinos. The panini sandwiches and salads are really good too. They also serve beer and wine and I believe they have a happy hour special on alcoholic beverages too :). 

The cafe is really comfy for reading, studying, chatting with friends, etc and provides free WiFi too! :) You can pick a table in the sunny windows, outside, or in a darker corner. 

Yum, yum, yum!
author: Meghan P.

description:
Lately, I've been on a small quiet cafe hunt. 

I use to live on the same block as Gallery Cafe, but those were back in the days .. way before I became a caffeine addict. Since I was in the neighborhood on a early Tuesday morning, with hours to spare, I gave this place a shot. Right when I entered, the server was so energetic, friendly, and attentive. My skinny latte was made to perfection and topped off with a beautiful swirl. The setting is very chill, with relaxing music, and plenty of chairs. Adding on, they have outdoor seating, so on a nice day .. you'll be able to enjoy a nice cup of coffee while watching the Cable Cars go by.
author: Brenda C.

description:
Ordered the pesto tomato parm sandwich. It was weak. Sister had the grilled cheese, even weaker and for some reason, had tomato in it. 

The coffee wasn't very flavorful but the location is nice... except for random trash everywhere.
author: Dominic C.

description:
There are worse ways to spend an afternoon than nibbling on a turkey cranberry sandwich, scooping a generous bowl of granola and yogurt, keeping up with the world thanks to the free wifi/plentiful outlets and sipping a good nonfat vanilla latte.

All while lounging at tables inside this friendly and roomy cafe that look out onto the cable cars crossing the Washington/Mason intersection.

There are much, much worse ways to spend an afternoon.
author: Jason B.

description: Cash only and the employees are pretty rude. Coffee is good but I wouldn't bother with any of their eats. Alright environment, if your in desperate need to go somewhere with WiFi.
author: Brian D.

description:
OVERALL:3.4   FOOD:3   SERVICE:3.5   AMBIANCE:4   VALUE:3
