Across from the Cable Car Museum, this is a spaciously cozy spot to people-watch, catch some Vitamin D on the sidewalk tables, enjoy some breakfast/coffee, and maybe even a cold pint at the bar!  Great balance of neighborhood locals and the occasional trickle of Euro tourists.

Mostly solid coffee (espresso drinks vary, depending on who's manning the steam wand), but I come mostly for the convenience, abundant seating, GQ library (I know, guilty pleasure!) constant art rotation, low-key vibe, and free wi-fi.  Menu features variety of simple sandwiches, salads, pastries, daily quiches, limited wine selection....haven't tried the breakfast, but looks reliable.  Sandwiches are pretty unremarkable and mostly just disappointing (think homemade, but not in the impressive way)....stick to the liquids.

Great place to spend a relaxing weekend!
author: Amy K.

description:
Coffee is only mediocre. And... the barista had no idea what a "dry" cappuccino was... I tried to explain... and the drink I got was very much a wet capuccino. This is why people so many people want to go to Peet's or Starbucks for good coffee!! and they rarely make a drink wrong. get it together! make your coffee good!

PS there are some exceptions, ie blue bottle and philz....
author: Claire b.

description:
"Gallery" Cafe.  More like "My-semi-retarded-child's-crayola-fingerpainting-nonsense-hanging-on-my-refrigerator-because-I-feel-guilty-when-he-pulls-that-shit-from-the-trash-can-and-looks-at-me-with-his-big-bovine-eyes" Cafe.

I didn't notice any "gallery." I checked the website--oddly, there is no mention of said eponymous gallery, only an asinine bio for Vincent Van Gogh. Pretension is a dish best served...not by the Gallery Cafe, the culinary equivalent of seven popped collars. 

I did, however, notice the potted-plant topiary decor.  No doubt aphid infested and ripped off from some local marijuana horticulturalist.  And the overpriced menu.  And the bad panini.  And the cardboard to-go cup in which I was made to enjoy my English Breakfast tea while sitting outside due to the cafe's unbearable heat and humidity, a function of its biodiversification, perhaps?

It was lucky that I was sitting outside eating my lackadaisical Mozarella Tomato Pesto panini, made with marshmallow for bread and anthrax for the rest, watching Amanda F. eat her anemic mixed green salad, because it was there I saw the only redeeming quality of the establishment and the only reason to write this review (otherwise, it would not have even deserved the generous star I've granted).

In front of the restaurant on the sidewalk, beyond the overhead scaffolding supports, with a backdrop of the historic Cable Car museum, there stood a city garbage receptacle, and a surprisingly kempt-looking elderly Chinese gentleman performing his civic duty and collecting the recyclables carelessly deposited in the trash can.

There were so many things that were right about that moment--me, suffering through the sulfur and brimstone on my plate, drinking from my Mother Earth destroying cardboard tea-cup, already scratching at the bug-bites I expected to leave with--and this guy, Champion of the Elements, Son of Man, earning a living while saving the environment even in his waning years, wearing a thick, rich overcoat of dignity.

My sandwich, ashen in my mouth.  My thirst only whetted by this soulless tea. And behold, this giant in front of me, crushing cans with his fist.

Places like the Gallery Cafe should be bulldozed like a Palestinian city block.
author: Donny S.

description: The two stars are simply because it is convenient and they provide WiFi.  But unfortunately I have been coming to this place for the past 5 years and it has not changed in cleanliness or decor.  It is sub-par if even that and it is not the cleanest place.  The only advantage they have in getting customers is that they are across the street from the cable car museum and tourists know no better.  The staff used to be nice but has turned rude.  The woman who works the cash register is only friendly to men and you almost feel like you are in a nail salon where you are being talked about behind your back.  I would appreciate it if the owner could put a bit of time and effort into cleaning up the place and making it presentable given this is almost the ONLY coffee shop in Nob Hill, minus the one in the Fairmont.  And needless it is over-priced.
author: Shirazi S.

description: Nice quite stop to take a break from walking Around. Ok sandwiches and drinks, cold beer.
author: Laura O.

description:
I always thought that Gallery Cafe is one of those cute little local places that would be fun to work at. Serving coffee, toasting bagels, all the while watching patrons sit outside in the sun drinking their lattes. 

Gallery Cafe makes a mean bagel and they always put on the tomatoes and red onions for me just right! The coffee is nice and strong, but a little expensive. They make breakfast sandwiches too with bacon that are delicious on a hungover Sunday morning. I live in the neighborhood and love to stop by. You can even wander into the cable car museum across the street if time allows.
author: Natalie N.

description: Regular coffee is ok and their ham egg and cheese is exactly what is expected. Toasted bagel properly, didn't have the sesame, not a big deal. Overall solid place for breakfast but not memorable or worth coming back for $5.35.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Love!  My new favorite coffee shop to study in.   With the exception of the cable cars rattling by, this is a relatively quiet cafe where you can relax, and unwind or study.  The people working  there are super nice and I get a nice ego boost when ordering (the people behind the counter look like dwarves because of the weird platform they've set up).  The coffee is pretty good as well as the sandwiches and bagels.  

There is free wifi here, and depending on where you're sitting, the signal can be pretty spotty....this is totally fine b/c wifi just sucks away time from the studying.  The music is usually very mellow.

You can totally hang around here the entire day without anyone really bugging you.  The only minus is that they only accept cash.
author: Guava C.

description:
I love small cafes like this and decided to try it after visiting the Cable Car Museum. They have a decent selection of sandwiches, panini, coffee, tea, and pastries. I'm always a fan of any place that serves grilled cheese, so I ordered that and an iced tea. The sandwich came with a good amount of cheese and tomato on white or wheat bread. My only complaint (and many a restaurants are guilty of this) is that the cheese was not all the way melted. It's a huge pet peeve of mine. If you offer grilled cheese, keep it on the grill long enough so it's completely melted! It was still good, though.

The inside had a decent number of seats inside and outside, plus a couch and it was still difficult to find an empty seat at lunchtime on a Saturday. I loved that they had books and magazines there so you could enjoy your food or drink with some reading material. I think they also had some games, too.
author: Marjie T.

description: This is my neighborhood cafe / coffee shop. I subtracted one star because it does not accept cards. Otherwise I love this place. The staff is always friendly. The coffee is always good. The food is always delicious. If you're in the neighborhood, stop in and grab a bite.
author: Danie D.

description:
Another of my walk-ta-work steadies.  The service is quite friendly and the coffee is also good.  I've got to knock 'em back a little since the sandwiches are not as good as some of their neighborhood peers.  The wheat bread really is just plain old, from a plastic bag wheat bread which can get a little soggy if you're on the go!

They are a great study stop though and have MUCH more space than any of the other places in the neighborhood.  Also they keep very regular hours.
author: Eric J.

description: About a year ago this place saved me from starving. I was in the area looking for some food and all the other nearby establishments were tourist traps. I was so relieved to have stumbled upon such a nice little cafe where I could have a decent sandwich and get my caffeine fix. Definitely an added bonus that they now serve beer and wine, great for those lazy afternoons. Cheers.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Everything about this place screams 'eh'
The food?   eh
The coffee? eh
The staff?   eh

I come here from time to time since it's the closest cafe to my house and they have outdoor seating.  Other than that?  Eh.
author: phil h.

description:
I liked the general layout and the sofa area.  I didn't much care for the cramped, rattle-y little tables in the windows.  The neighborhood is definitely a challenge but there's lots of residential in that area and they deserve a good cafe.  I've only been for an event, but I would definitely come back for the free wi-fi and decent coffee and comfy sofa seating in front of the big teevee.

I also liked the amount and kind of art they seemed to be selecting for the walls, particularly the Filipino-American artist who is up there now.
author: Kevin S.

description:
This place is screaming for a makeover. Apart from the filth in every container and crevice, there's this overwhelming malaise ... the ghost of something past, I don't know.

If there's one plus it's the location: right next door to a laundromat, which means you don't have to watch your clothes go round and round and round and ....
author: Max A.

description:
So-so coffee house with a few sandwiches, breakfast items, salads, etc.  The big space is underused.  Not a fan of the dercor of exposed plywood, spray-on ceiling plaster, a ladder and, office depot / target level furniture.  The couches are shady as far as spillage and vermin population.  Music volume to bearability ratio is off by half.

Plus side is that it's sunny and open in the afternoon, it's across from the Cable Car barn, and the wine selection is good if a bit expensive when not on happy hour.

Free wifi.
author: Gil S.

description: "Shiho!  I found my new coffee spot!"  I had found Gallery Cafe thanks to Emily H. my roommate when we lived on 800 block of Mason.  This was back in 2005.  I recently found my frequent customer card while doing some cleaning (yeah I know... stuff from 2005 emerged like no other).  I loved trotting over the hill to visit this cafe.  Great soy lattes and treats.
author: Shiho F.

description: This is my neighborhood go-to breakfast spot. It's a bit overpriced and cash only, so come prepared. They've got good quiche and overall a cool atmosphere. Sit outside if it's a nice day.
author: Adam D.

description: Sort of an odd location, but a cool one right by the cable car museum.  They have free internet for those like me that shun laptops.  A nice big screen projection TV with the A's game on when I was there.  Comfortable and varying types of seating and tables.  Friendly workers, good clean bathrooms.  Would have to return again to give another review when free wine not available which may be biasing my opinion.
author: Marc S.

description:
I enjoyed the drinks & HH at Gallery Cafe, but the truth is I still see it more as (surprise) a Cafe and maybe a Gallery. At the Yelp event, one of the barristas/bartenders made me a special mango concoction (amazing)...besides that, I think I'd stick w/ a tea or coffee if I was to return. 

The best thing about this place (besides the wonderful smiling staff) is the cafe itself. I adore all the windows..And those intimate NOOKS & CRANNIES..oooh!  With the numerous large windows and the front door coming to a point, I felt as if I was on a wooden deck of a classic ship... I wanted to hang off the edge with my hair waving like Leonardo...

Comforted by the narrow streets of Nob Hill, and the passing trolley cars, I felt like a true San Franciscan at the Gallery Cafe! In the rare case I'm back in that area, I'd definitely stop in...but, I'd wear my slippers & PJs and get all snuggly in a corner.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I don't eat oatmeal unless I need to regularize myself, you dig? Of course you do. Or unless I'm at work and don't want to be poisoned by cafeteria food. I believe in breakfast, even when it's covered in brown sugar.

HOWEVER Gallery Cafe? They make theirs with soy milk and honey. It might sound unimpressive, but holy shit this is oatmeal?? It's candy in a bowl! I'd eat it every morning if I could be super late to work and always had cash on me.
author: Shannon V.

description:
Gallery Cafe, situated at a cable car crossroads, is the first checkpoint after the initial steep descent from the tip top of Nob every morning on my walk to work.  I am renewed with a hot cup of house dark roast.  Bringing a commuter cup is always preferable-- their cups are a bit small (order a small and you will get TINY) and are prone to coffee jumping out of the spout and onto your work shirt. 

The floor behind the counter is almost a foot lower than the rest of the cafe, which gives me the extra boost of self-confidence I need to kick off the day.  There are computers available for use in the corner if you didn't bring your laptop to enjoy the free WiFi.  The enjoyment is cut off around 7pm, and you'll have to migrate to another hotspot up and over the hill if you want to keep surfing.
author: Marjorie B.

description:
Im sad to say, but the gallery cafe is on the road to dumpsville...the new owners, while cool, nice guys, have turned it from a great neighborhood cafe into a tourist trap...goodbye good sandwiches, poetry nights, cute cafe boys and awesome music...hello crappy music (I swear I heard the backstreet boys, at 8am no less) played at deafening loud levels, higher prices and good coffee, plus these annoying frappacino or whatever the heck they are signs everywhere. 
Please gallery cafe, bring back the good sando-s (and I dont mind paying $8 for a sandwich if its tasty) coffee and music...its not too late!
author: Kelly F.

description:
I'm always pretty happy when I make the trip over to this sunny cafe on a quiet little corner. The coffee is pretty great,  the sandwiches are good (if a little overpriced for what you are getting) and the staff is always easygoing, enjoyable and cute. I could easily see this being a good place in your neighborhood to do whatever-it-is-you'd-do-at-home but when you would rather do it somewhere else.

That said, the BEST part about the GC is the counter where you order. Let me explain. Clearly they have the customer in mind, because the person that takes your order is standing about a foot below you. This makes you feel super tall and really really good about yourself, which in turn makes your food & drink taste that much better and therefore your whole day takes a positive turn. Why don't all establishments do this?? The world would be a more peaceful place if they did, FO SHO.
author: Chris L.

description: A nice little place in an unexpected location - it definitely fills a void for the neighborhood. I thought the alcoholic drinks were actually quite nice, and the restaurant was comfortable, if not a tad bleak. The food was respectable too. A-OK, but not soul-shaking.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Hills, cable cars, coffee, tea, picture windows, free wifi, outdoor seating, AND art--they thought of everything here.  I order up their chai latte.  Milky spiced tea warms my tummy as I nestle into a window seat.  The blissful smile I wear lets the world know there's something good going on here.

Note: They close at 7:30pm during these winter months.  Too early for my taste.  Stay open later, GC!
author: M A N I K.

description:
Stopped by to kill some time before a movie this afternoon. They had what we needed: 

A bathroom, complete with gianormous pipe attached to the key

Espresso, complete with pretty latte art

Couches to curl up on and bitch about boys

The desserts and food looked yummy, but we were too stuffed from dim sum to eat anything.
author: Lauren H.

description: Our cable car had a maintenance stop, so we hopped off and wandered into the Gallery Café. Was a great spot for a healthy and tasty breakfast bite.  Bagel sandwich with lox & cream cheese was great, as was the goat cheese Panini.  Coffee and Espresso too.  Casual, neighborhood spot with tables indoors and out.  Nice find!
author: Carolyn C.

description: This is a cute spot to grab a coffee before walking down to bart in the morning. My friend lived right by here and she took me here often to grab a nice iced latte and a breakfast pastry. There's always people here on their lap top or reading a book. It's a nice place to check out if you are in the area.
author: Stephanie U.

description:
Perfect spot for a Saturday Suduko marathon.  Mellow, good natural light, relatively quiet, and plenty of tables.  I cheated on my coffee detox here.  It was worth it!  The coffee is really good!  Other reviews are right.  Not at all overroasted or bitter.  

I almost subtracted one star because the barrista gave me some attitude.  He looked annoyed because I spent more than 32 seconds contemplating the merits of poppy seed bread versus an egg and cheese sandwich.  Understandable if there was a line but there wasn't. I hadn't had coffee for days.  My brain was operating at the speed of a 386.  Give me a break!  Nevertheless, Mr. Sourpuss did not ruin my morning.  And after a few sips of Joe I was back to myself.
author: sarah k.

description: Over priced for what it is. Adequate food. Cash only. Would only go back if it were close to where I was and if I were starving
author: A L.

description:
One of the best chill cafes in town.  
The clientele is quite, intellectual and cool.
author: Peter O.

description: Great spot. I love that you can avoid the hub-bub that a downtown S-bucks has to offer. Free wi-fi...beer...so yea, thats about all you need. That and quiet.
author: Josh A.

description:
I enjoy setting up shop here every couple of days or so. Very cozy place for working on your laptop (with the requisite free wi-fi, of course). Lots of seating options, including outside tables if that's your thing. The food is good (I love their egg and bagel sandwich), and the coffee always hits the spot.

It's right across from the Cable Car museum and a crossing -- I saw some people remark that it's noisy, but I personally love the ambiance the location brings.

only caveat is cash only, but there's also an ATM inside.
author: Chris M.

description: I stopped here for an iced americano as I was walking home from the Chinatown library. The drink tasted good, and I appreciated how much room he left for milk. I'm intrigued by this place because I really like the layout. There are all these nooks in separate bay windows for two people to sit, a nice patio, and the inside is really spacious. They have a very similar menu to the Chameleon, similar pastries, but I'm not sure what coffee they use. I also appreciated the huge wooden drum with free novels for patrons to read. I will probably stop by again to sample other drinks and see how skillful the baristas are.
author: Merrilee T.

description: Cozy atmosphere. Good sandwiches but expensive. Good coffee. Lukewarm staff.
author: Travis L.

description:
I used to live around the block from this place, so this review might be a little dated. When I was there, though, this used to be my second home. 

They pull a great shot of espresso, and with the cable car museum right across the street this happens to be a pretty swell people watching spot. Good wine/beer selection...tasty food and pastries...the white chocolate macadamia cookies...mmmmm....
author: Geof M.

description:
Back when Estrella was pulling espressos this place was five stars.  But she left for another business and the quality has been in gradual decline since.  They still use great beans but the newer Baristas don't seem to be as conscientious as in the past.

Still, Gallery cafe has great price to quality ratio for their coffee and food, especially compared to the competition down the road in North Beach.  And the scene is great -- an even mix of locals, tourists from the cable car museum, and even the occasional group of cable car operators getting their morning cup of Joe.
author: Phill W.

description:
This cafe is never crowded, so it's very quiet and relaxing save for the cable cars rumbling by.  Service was always friendly.  The counter has a strange setup where the barista seems a lot shorter than you.  Subliminal message of subserviency..?

I think their drinks are a little pricey for the size you get, but they make some mean sandwiches!!  Their lox bagel is a favorite of mine and the bacon, egg, and cheese bagel comes complete with big, fat strips of bacon dripping with grease.  I tried the asparagus quiche, and it was o.k.  I'd stick with the bagels, mmm toasty.  Oh, and remember- CASH ONLY.
author: Jennie L.

description:
This is a great place that feels like a quaint, neighborhood cafe, with the added perk of watching tourists go by on cable cars.  

AND you've gotta love a cafe that serves beer and wine.  Don't miss the happy hour starting at 3p, where they serve beer on tap for $2.50!
author: Tara T.

description:
You know that local coffee shop that if you go to enough people start knowing your name?  The other day the sweet lady at the counter asked me "the usual?"  I knew I was in.

Gallery is a great place to bring a laptop to work (free wi-fi) or just to have a nice cup of Chai Latte on a nice day.  It is spacious, nice staff, and good food.  

Remember to wave the the tourists as the cable car rolls by.  They love it.
author: James B.

description: I'd have to say this is one my best kept secrets.  The staff are friendly and they have lots to offer....light music, quiet place for studying, free internet (if you bring your own laptop), and a variety of food.  I like this place because it's never busy and it's so quiet.  Ok, I haven't tried everything on the menu...but I always get the gorgonzola salad (pretty big).  The other times, I just get a pastry or whatever is left in the display case (almond croissant and apple filled pastry???).  Otherwise, I just order a drink...black iced tea, french soda, or coffee.  Ok, I'd have to admit, the coffee stinks (watery...blah).  But it beats going to Starbucks where they blast the music and a not-so peaceful atmosphere.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I moved north of Market a little more than two months ago, and I finally have begun exploring the neighborhood. 

I took a walk over to Gallery Cafe today to meet up with a friend who had been there before. What a gorgeous walk over there! Coming up Powell Street I had a great view of St. Peter and Paul Church - the one on washington square with two spires - and the bay, and even that bridge that isn't the GG or the Bay Bridge, north of the City. whatever it's called.

Back to the cafe: it is very cute, spacious, and does have little nooks and crannies where you can sit and be somewhat hidden from everyone else by plants and half a wall. They have a good, typical selection of espresso drinks, teas, juices, italian sodas, a decent breakfast menu (mainly eggs and meat on bagels), panini, pastries, and cake. 

Oh, and free wifi. They're across the street from the cable car museum which is a very cute all brick building. I'd definitely come back.
author: Jacqui M.

description:
Location is probably the best thing about Gallery Cafe.

Situated directly across The Cable Car Museum, a laundromat, and only a block away from the Chinatown Branch Public Library, Gallery Cafe is about the only coffee place in the entire Nob Hill.

The cafe itself is rather spacious and has got a nice neighborhood feel to it. It's a comfy spot to hang out with a friend, read a book, work on the laptop, or just watch the tourist go by on the Cable Car.

The coffee and pastries are a bit sub-par for people like me who are used to the conglomerate tastes of Starbucks, Peet's, or Coffee Bean. Nonetheless, Gallery Cafe is a nice little coffee shop for those around the area.
author: Tommy T.

description:
This place is a winner.  Pleasant intersection, with big windows for loads of non-glaring, natural sunlight.  Internet and just the right amount of ambient noise and music. The food was pretty good and the staff was very friendly.   I'm gonna be a regular.  If repeat experiences match my first one, I'll bump this up to a fiver.

UPDATE: Alright, so I'm bumping this up to a fiver.  Repeat experiences were up to par.  Get the chicken dishes (panini, salad).. they are tender and moist!  The only complaint I would have is that it tends to get pretty hot inside the cafe on sunny days.  But that is to be expected given the large windows, open kitchen, and lights.  I would look into installing some quiet fans to help bring in outside air.
author: Calvin N.

description:
Its right around the corner from my house, and also across from the cable car museum.
All barista can do the lovely espresso art.
It's a nice place to go relax and chat or do some reading.
author: Mai K.

description:
I stumbled across this gem while going for a walk around and about in the Nob Hill area. Plenty of natural light, seating, and non-obnoxious music playing in the back ground.

I ordered the mocha and caramel apple pie, both of which I think about to this day, and took a seat in a window alcove while my snack was being made.

The staff seemed friendly enough, though I seemed to get a little bit of a 'tude from the cashier. I think I had the tourist look going on that day, so I won't ding them a star for that.

There is a large bottled beer selection as well as wine, plenty of seating, and EZ access to the Hyde Cable Car. Don't try to drive here, there are no garages to spare and most of the block is permit parking for Cable Car drivers(?!). 

I didn't test out the wifi, but one person asked about wifi and informed it was "free to use", no passwords!
author: Mark B.

description:
When I saw the Turkey Cranberry sandwich on the menu it brought back delectable memories of The Bobbie (http://www.yelp.com/biz/I3yzZhtKfRMuUHWHDBqHGA) back home.  I was never expecting it to match the culinary perfection that is The Bobbie, but I was hoping for close.  Not so much.  The sandwich wasn't bad, but had way too much balsamic vinaigrette - I'll be trying something different next time.

Its quiet and has free wi-fi so locals come here to catch up on school work or just surf online outside of their homes.  I'm not a huge coffee drinker but proximity, price and a decent menu will keep me coming back.
author: Chuck C.

description:
Yes, it is the closest establishment to my apartment and that may create a bias, but I'm ok with that. I still love my corner cafe. The tables in the windows are great for pausing for contemplation while doing whatever it is you are doing on that laptop. The sights and sounds of the cable cars are soothing to me, but if you aren't used to it, bring headphones. 

Prices aren't bad compared to a lot of places. Love the little leaf they make in your latte foam... or maybe I'm just easily entertained.
author: Jenn M.

description:
The coffe is okay but service takes a little longer than it should.  I've had pastries and breakfast bagels; I would steer you, gentle reader, towards the breakfast bagels rather than the pastries.

There are plenty of places to sit, usually.  I have not yet checked out their wifi/internet offering.
author: Ian T.

description:
I've been to Gallery Cafe more times than I can possibly remember. Seated right across from the Cable Car Museum, Gallery Cafe is a nice neighborhood cafe. there's free wifi and its cash only.They've changed ownership a while ago and now runs more organized than before, but also lost the personality they uniquely had from the previous generation of employees. The current staff is nice and friendly, like any Starbucks.

The coffee remains a good quality, food is ok and there are delivered desserts, but sadly seems to rise in price faster than gas. The cafe is laid out well inside and out, the window table are especially nice little spots to read or work on your laptop. Local artists show there, and they rotate them frequently enough. Its the main appeal of Gallery Cafe, the ambiance. The location, sound, light, and locals (with a good mix of tourists)...  Its a good place to spend your afternoon.
author: Ivan M.

description: I would love to give this 5 stars since it's round the corner, but I can't even give it one....or maybe one..........it does not have an inviting atmosphere at all.....I popped in for a happy hour wine, but oh dear, wine is not on the happy hour list ...$6.50 for a glass of medicocre wine from trader joe's, ...i guess I am an idiot........maybe they should write that on the chalkboard outside - only beer..............the music was way too loud, radio channel even though there were a total of 2 inside....night club bad music......I eventually had to ask the guy to turn it down...what a shame it is such a dingy place, such a great location......
author: carl c.

description: I used to walk a lot at lunch when I worked downtown. Sometimes my route would take me up Mason Street from the Union Square area. I remember seeing this cute cafe on the corner across from the Cable Car Museum many times but I never went in. I did not know what I was missing!! Nice ambiance inside with a lot of comfortable seating. Its a great place to go to have a good cup of coffee or an espresso drink and a snack. It's also a great place to bring your laptop and get work done! I love the free and fast wifi that they offer!!
author: Lisa M.

description: A bit of a letdown. It was the first time I've ever left a mocha unfinished. It tasted a little odd. I went back a few days after and the experience was a ton better. Three stars.
author: Peter K.

description: Great coffee and pastries and you can watch the cable cars turn a corner.  Its close to Chinatown and across the street from the Cable Car museum (worth a visit).  Despite its proximity to so much tourism, it still has a local feel.
author: Mike T.

description: This café is at a very convenient place at the Nob Hil. It provides you with free wi-fi but the service is very weak. Check the opening hours before entering, as they might sell a cup of coffee and tell you to leave after 10 min due to the business hours.
author: Matti P.

description: Nice small cafe in my neighborhood. Similar to all the others around here, has wifi and a decent selection of sandwiches
author: Luke R.

description: Stopped in for a quick lunch. Reasonable selection of sandwiches, paninis bacon and eggs on the menu board, some baked items which didn't appear house made. I thought my sandwich was average at best.
author: Sara S.

description: When I was a little girl I always wanted to play with the life-sized mannequins in Macy's display windows in Union Square. Unfortunately, I never had the guts or the brains to figure out how to get in there. Much to my delight, however, I was able to sit in a display window at this cute little cafe. The tables in the nooks are so cool - and they made my childhood dream come true - sort of.
author: Jane K.

description: This little place is right between my office and home.  Cute litle place, with decent coffee. Love sitting outside, especially in this area.
author: Dee H.

description: It's really nice to have such great place to enjoy coffee and go online while I white for a phone call to meet up with my freelance.  If not for this I would not know what to do.  Good thing it's only two block from where I have to meet up with my freelance.  It's right across the street from the SF cable car museum.  By the way, I have to say the guy that works at the Cable Car Museum is super nice, that's what I'm gonna yelp about next.
author: Xiu L.

description: Sweet little spot in Nob Hill to kick back and relax with your laptop over a cup of coffee or casually woop it up with some wine or beer. Can you casually woop it up? Well, a bunch of us Yelpers did on Friday and it makes a great space for whatever you feel like doing. It was nice and cozy and clean. And the help was super cool, even to all of us who hopped off the goofy Yelp train. I'd like to come back and spend a rainy day here on my computer with their coffee...
author: Michael E.

description: Warm cafe setting with friendly staff and good food and drink options.  I'll definitely go back when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Rebecca G.

description: First, I'll say that I like this location simply because it brings me to another corner of the city - I am all about exploring new places.  The cable car also adds an element of "Oh how very San Francisco."  Loren, the owner is very nice, as were the bartenders.  I'll definately go back and sample more of what this cute little cafe has to offer.
author: Sarah S.

description: They meet the first cafe requirement admirably, which is that they have tasty, strong coffee.  (Extra points for the staff's ability to do that cool, swirly pattern trick in latte foam.) This place is on my route to work, so I can say that the coffee quality is consistent.  The atmosphere is great, with big, sunny windows, window tables on an elevated platform, and interesting, non-intrusive world music playing.  I wasn't impressed by the one sandwich I've had there (ham & melted brie), but the variety of sandwiches makes me want to try again.
author: Martha T.

description:
hmmmmmmmmmmmmm...


this place is outrageously expensive. $3 friggin dollars for a SNICKERDOODLE????????????

uhh... no thanks, i'll get an italian soda for $3.50+tax. THAT is reasonable.

the sandwiches take too long to make. 

enh.

its not wonderful, its not crappy, its....

enh.

i dunno. 

: I
author: Inari T.

description: First of all, I came here because it is literally a few doors from where I live.  However, the amazing coffee and free internet access keep me coming back!  I detest overly burned coffee beans like Starbucks, Pete's (spelling?), et al.  These guys have it just right.  Moreover, the water pitchers usually have lemon, lime, or even cucumber slices in them.  I never thought cucumber water would be good, but now I find it more quenching than Gatorade.  Interesting particleboard floors and a friendly staff cap the experience.  Absolute tops!
author: Alex H.

description: I started coming because of the proximity to my house, and keep coming back for an occasional latte or beer on tap! they do a happy hour 3-6, i think, where the beers are pretty reasonable. a great spot to sit out on the corner and watch the tourists and cable cars go by. Super friendly staff and location makes up for the  mediocre coffee
author: mike s.

description: This place is good if u wanna work without disruption for a few hours but the hot drinks are always soo hot that u burn your mouth - i never had such hot coffee or tea drinks somewhere else and i feel its annoying as u have to wait 10 min to be able to drink it and then the coffee is really nothing special and not really tasty.  But as said - if u wanna work quietly and have a chai latte (which is good but way too hot too) u can go here
author: Johana S.

description: Beer, Wine, Coffee and free internet access...how can you go wrong?  Great service and nice atmosphere.  I walked from Bart up the hill and took the cable car back...I felt like a kid again.
author: Matthew P.

description: I'm definately going back to this place. Very nice neighborhood and extremely friendly and attentive bartenders. This is a place where you can casually walk in, watch a game, go online, sip a cup of coffee and relax for the weekend.
author: Michael K.

description: Excellent coffee and atmosphere.  Fun photographs litter the back wall and the internet access is free and fast.  The cookies are AWESOME!  Only glitch...I've never had service with a smile.
author: ellyk E.

description: My neighborhood cafe. Great coffee and a charming staff.  The GC is an integral part of my morning ritual.
author: Kezia P.

description: Gallery's a nice chill out place.  It's even better if you can nab a window seat.  It's fun watching the tourists roll by, their faces in awe, as they hang onto the cable car.  The projection screen is cool, too.  The coffee is good, and staff are friendly.  If you're hoofing it, depending on where you're coming from, you can get a good workout due to its location as it's surrounded by hilly streets.
author: Marsha Z.

description: One of the few cafes that have La Colombe coffee and make it as it should be made...the lattes are foamy and full of flavor and if the barista is really daring he will make a little design for you with steamed milk (oooo, aahhhh)!  Their quiches and sandwiches are yummy and the owner is always trying new things with his menu...This place is evolving into a neighborhood destination--it plays movies at night, offers good beer and wine, and has different events with artists.  It's also good place to sit in the sun during the day and watch all the tourists pass by in cable cars...
author: Jaena G.

description: Holy meatballs!!  Really, they were freaking good!  I am a pseudo vegetarian, but I still mananged to eat about ten of those meaty bites of love!  Great place to hang out, snack have a beer or a some.  Take the cable care if you can.
author: Amme P.

description: This is my favorite little local cafe. Every time I come here I'm just instantly relaxed and happy. Free Wi-Fi, excellent cappucinos, amazing-looking quiches (...I haven't actually tried one yet), and great service... There are a couple of places nearby that feel rushed and anxious; Gallery has the perfect coffee shop atmosphere.
author: Ali T.

description: Finally, a cafe in my neighborhood that reminds me of Berkeley's Strada or Milano.  They have free wireless here, which is totally deserving of 5 stars, in addition, their coffee is a great medicine for hangovers.  I love the tables outside, perfect for a nice breezy day in the city.  If not, there are comfy couches indoors, ideal for fulfilling any desire to finish a great novel.  For me, this is my spot for some journal writing.  They also serve great food here and dessert to die for.  The only downside to this cafe is the possibility of running into an ex-bf, but any true and honest yelper would never let that be a reason of one decreasing star.
author: Wendy H.

description:
the space is large and comfortable and well lit from light streaming through the large expanse of glass in the front. there is ample seating around the place (17 tables/33 seats, plus a big couch area) which includes two nice, private-ish nooks in the front window which would great for a date or hanging out with your significant other. the entire space is clean and organized, but maybe a little too much... like i'm at a someone's house who has painstakingly aligned everything with a ruler. (4)

their food selection is ok - i saw a lot of quiche available at the counter... i guess they haven't read that one book. ;) (3)

the WiFi is free and was definitely cranking when i was last there: 11650/2100 (5)

the place is a little off the beaten path and there's not a good way to get there by bike - it seems to be uphill in all directions. though once you're there the place is brightly lit and welcoming. the bench seating is slightly padded so it's good for longer work stretches. there is some power for laptops but you might have to look; the window seats are a good bet for that. the staff behind the counter are nice and seemed to be really efficient. (+1)

so, as part of my search to find a great cafe in which to work, Gallery cafe gets a solid 4.3 stars.
author: FrOg SoU P.

description: Not really my favorite coffee, and it's somehow more expensive than starbucks. Be that as it may, it's the only cafe within a block from me so I go here most days and the people who work there are really nice. They also make good sandwiches but I've always stayed suspicious of the pastries.
author: Constance C.

description: This place is quite nice, lots of windows and places to sit along with some internet access. Though I must admit I've only been here once and it was for a Yelp event.  Not that it's a bad thing but it just happened to be well off my beaten path and so it's probably not a place I will frequent.  They put on a nice shindig for us all to get together with some nice drinks and yummy appetizers.  I would definately recommend it to anyone in the area looking for a drink or some coffee and a snack.
author: Derek D.

description: Nice location, good place to work, friendly staff, not crowded, but fairly weak wifi and they only accept cash.
author: Eric W.

description:
this seems like the sort of place i'd go to if i lived in the neighborhood.

i do not live in the neighborhood.  i am not moving anytime soon.
author: Samantha W.

description: Strong coffee and a nice place to do some work, it's right outside a cable car stop too, that's really cool. They just started serving beer and wine, which makes Gallery Cafe the perfect spot to unwind for a casual happy hour amongst good friends, also to heckle/wave to tourists as they cable car on by.
author: Nish N.

description: The coffee is weak and the food is uninspiring. But it's the closest cafe to where I live so I end up going there quite a bit. It's well priced, never crowded and there's free wi-fi so that totally makes up for what it lacks. Cute little neighborhood cafe that covers all the bases but doesn't quite hit a home run in my book.
author: Natalie T.

description:
This cafe was awesome when Violet, Shane, Shawn, and Kyle worked there. It was the neighborhood cafe, with a great art vibe, awesome coffee, and those guys who are awesome to talk to. Unfortunately Lauren sold the cafe, and things have changed quite a bit. The cafe went from neighborhood friendly, to tourist friendly, which is a sad phenomenon here in San Francisco. Lauren used to give the locals small discounts and perks. That all went away. The cool guys that worked there were fired, and replaced by coffee-shop clones with no personality. The prices went up, and the quality of the food choices went down. The sandwiches used to be made on this heavenly bread, now they are made on cheap supermarket bread. The bagel breakfast sandwiches used to be extraordinary, now they are mediocre and oily. 
Gone is the delicious strawberry rhubarb pie from Aunt Nettie's, now replaced by some Costco lemon cream concoction.
The new owners are nice enough, but obviously concerned with making money instead of keeping the integrity and character of this business.
The coffee is excellent still, as they use La Colombe which is hard to screw up, but still I get the odd espresso shot that has been burned.
Gallery Cafe, your golden years are gone.
author: Caro T.

description: I've had better coffee, but what a fantastic location! I sat there for 2 hours today watching the cable cars pass by and the tourists come and go. I'll have to go back and get something dessert-ish and see if that bumps up my score another star.
author: Fawn F.

description: This is my local coffee shop and it has a special place in my heart. The staff is really nice, hard-working, and positive. Often they have huge lines of customers and they never huff or puff, they just do the work with a smile and even manage to bring dishes to the tables while servicing the line. They are always sweet to my rambunctious two year old, and the wifi is a life saver when mine goes down (which is often). The owner is always there working alongside his employees, and the vibe is great! The art changes regularly and its usually inspiring. Most of my mornings begin here and I wouldn't have it any other way! The only change I would make is I would bring some more progressive items to the menu, like gluten-free treats and healthier breakfast choices. The menu just needs a little inspiration to make this place perfect.
author: Virginia J.

description:
great ambience and location - just up and over the hill from my apartment, with cable cars going by and progressive / down tempo beats in the background, and great lighting.
their food is ok - their oatmeal, served wtih steamedmilk was a kinda runny.  their organic chai was very smooth.

great place to "work from home" - free wifi too.
author: Haru K.

description:
i actually like this place, its kind of fun to watch the turon action outside everytime the cable car stops and occaisionally a cute girl wanders in to distract me.

unfortunately, distraction by my computer is hampered by a horrendously slow internet connection. they stream music to itunes and frequently there are a bunch of laptops and their own rental boxes using the same slow connection. it seems to me that they ought to spend the extra 10 bucks and open up the pipe a little.  i talked to some of the employees and with a clueless smile they looked at their computer. obviously not worth the effort. 

so for internet and coffee, i now go elsewhere... too bad.
author: tommy p.

description: Good paninis, good quiche, good beverage selection, and there's always a place to sit. I'm deducting a star because there's not an avocado to be found on the premises, and I think that's just ridiculous.
author: Christina S.

description: Nothing Earth-shattering about this place, but it was a perfectly lovely spot to meet up with some out-of-town friends who were staying at a hotel nearby. I ordered a cafe au lait and a water and when the total was only $3.50 I thought maybe the guy forgot to ring me up for the water because it seemed like such a value. But nope! $3.50 for the whole enchilada!
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Lovely little spot to enjoy on a nice day and just people watch and enjoy the city. The desserts and drinks are pretty tasty and from a non-sandwich person, the sandwiches were actually pretty good! Prices are extremely reasonable, there is free WiFi and the people are nice. I can't say anything bad about it at all.
author: Anita B.

description: Awesome little place!! Excellent for people watching, coffee and chit chat. Very laid back vibe with outdoor and indoor seating to enjoy the gorgeous San Francisco weather. I ordered the soy latte and it was pretty good. Not happy that they didn't have brown sugar but oh well. We sat in one of the cool window seats and seriously, that's what sold me on the place! I would have given it five stars yet the service was not great at all. In fact I think the woman who took my order hates her job. She may want to rethink her options. Otherwise, well worth the cable car ride out of the hood for a little catch up with an old friend!
author: Stephanie J.

description: I stumbled upon this place in my usual search for food, drink, wifi, and power outlets. What a gem! The food is basic but classy. There's plenty of seating. You can sit on the sidewalk and watch dorky tourists getting on cable cars. Nice place to relax if you around china town looking for a place to rest. Lucky I have cash though, it's cash only. You get another star when you take my plastic.
author: Jesse H.

description: The coffee and food are strictly OK but the ambience is lovely. I just wish they would be open later........they close at 7 pm!!!! Its one of my favorite places to study but very inconvenvient during weekdays when I barely get home by 7 pm.
author: Rumesha A.

description:
monday night once a month (1st monday maybe) there is a poetry night. well i was there a few days ago for that.  very creative people, some with their own published poetry books even.  and their creativity extends beyond writing clever reviews on yelp!  ;-)  the cafe opened extra late that night to accommodate the open mic. even though the people there didn't really eat or drink much and other customers didn't come in during the poetry hour.  in other words, the cafe didn't just stay open for the pursuit of capitalism.  i will take that over any chain coffee place any day.

most importantly - how were the eats?  since i was there late at night, and i can't drink coffee past 3 in the afternoon w/o being jittery all night - i can't speak for the coffee.  the quiche there was really good - with black olives, artichokes, *and* mushrooms (three of my fav. veggies) - and a bit of side salad with balsamic dressing came with it too.
author: Celeste L.

description: Another day at a new cafe and I really enjoyed my afternoon at Gallery. First off, it's very spacious and clean, and I was able to find a great spot to plug in right by the window.  Internet is free and the staff is very friendly. I ended up ordering a turkey/cranberry sandwich and then treated myself to a slice of pumpkin pie.  It was all VERY good!
author: Shawna H.

description: I'm sitting here, enjoying a delicious tuna melt sandwich, listening to a mix between tribal and 80s music, and surfing on their free wireless. Can't beat that!
author: andreas b.

description:
When I lived in Chinatown I went here EVERY SINGLE DAY.  My roommate and I would meet our friend to do our laundry at the Fashion Laundromat (best name for a laundromat EVER) and while we were waiting for our clothes to dry we would drink way too much coffee.  Then, I got a job there.  And I loved it even more.  This is a place that takes its coffee seriously.  When I later worked at La Boulange on Union street  I was appalled by their espresso crafting.  At gallery, they gave me a series of videos on how to make espresso drinks.  Videos.  Like I was supposed to go home and study how to make the perfect cappucino.  Like I said, very serious.  And you can definitely taste the difference.
The actual space is really lovely.  I love the big windows, the sun reflecting off the honey colored tables, the (usually) really cool art on the walls.  Also, it's a good place to get a beer at happy hour.  If I remember correctly they have some sort of two for one deal.  
I was so sad when I moved away.  The coffee at Gallery is so good it pretty much ruined me.  Since then, no other coffee has compared.  It's some special coffee that they only serve at like the French Embassy or something.  
The only reason I'm giving 4 stars is because it's no longer a block away from my house.
author: melissa r.

description: This is right around the corner from where I'm currently staying.  My friend told me that if I was in need of a wifi connection, I should check this place out.  At first I went there for a cup of coffee for breakfast, but having been in this city for a little under 2 weeks, I have been going there at least once a day.  My favorite has been sitting down to one of their books (they have reading material ranging from books, magazines to the newspaper for cafe dwellers) and enjoying my fare.  They have plenty of seating available, with tables, benches and couches.  A great spot to relax with a cup of coffee/tea and your laptop!
author: Aishah I.

description: Perfect place to lounge! Loved the sofas, smoked salmon sandwiches with mixed greens salad, italian soda, cafe mocha, paintings on the walls (it changes every two weeks i think), seasonal live musicians, nice background music, perfect place to get free internet access, friendly servers,  no boring moments!!!!
author: christy c.

description: this is my favorite cafe and place to study! free wi-fi, loads of outlets for laptops. i've been coming here for years now. it used to be very stuffy, but they recently added sliding windows that keep this place cool. the grilled chicken panini for $7.25 with a side salad. overall a great place to get some studying done. there is also beautiful art for sale that are displayed all over the cafe. they also have two computers for use if you purchase their wi-fi card. oh and its cash only!
author: Jen P.

description: great coffee and bagels...i miss this place  sunny egg with turkey bagel...
author: Dawn P.

description: *great* coffee, perfectly made lattes with the swirly little heart of foam, tasty little fresh-baked treats, free internet, and a laid back atmosphere.  my kind of place.
author: B R.

description: What a pearl!  This cool little cafe is nestled in between the honking cars and busy establishments, offering a little bit of Europe.  In search of coffee one Saturday morning during a weekend overnight in the city, my husband refused to go to Starbucks.  So in search of something more ambiance and less mainstream, we saw the open door and heard music coming from the Gallery Cafe.  The owner couldn't have been more personal, the coffee hit the mark, and the surroundings brought us back to wonderful memories of Europe.  We'll be back!
author: Mary R.
